trail_name: Bonneville Shoreline to Coldwater Canyon - North Ogden
description:
A climber's delight, this section of trail is the newest addition to the Bonneville Shoreline Trail, known as the 'BST.'  It appears this trail was finished in the spring of '15.  

You can start at North Ogden Nature Center Trailhead and climb the old jeep trail up to the BST. It's well-marked and fairly obvious. However, this area can see a lot of traffic.  When you get to the trail, head north.  

The first 1/2 mile is fairly rugged. Once you round the corner at the first small canyon (Garner Canyon), stay right and pass over a small bridge (taking the small rocky trail on the left will take you to a canal service road, and you'll have to make a short climb back to the trail).  Climb the 2 switchbacks, and follow the trail for as far as you want to go.  Once you get into the southern entrance of Coldwater Canyon, prepare yourself for a steep, exposed and loose narrow trail. 

After almost all the climbing, you'll reach the eastern end of the canyon and see a pump station on your left and a service road on your right.  I suppose you could bail here, but you've worked hard to get this far... I recommend climbing a little further so you can enjoy a little more of the downhill!  The northern side of the canyon is wider and proves an easier climb out.  

Did I mention the views? They're stunning!  You'll climb through several canyons.  They're a great place to cool off, and one might even have water coming down.  The higher you go, the more stunning the views become...  Willard Peak and Ben Lomond Peak are begging to be photographed!

Getting back to the car is easy - a quick hike down Mountain Road will put you right where you started.  Or, you could just hike the trail back to your car!

Miner's Basin Trail is a beautiful singletrack high altitude trail in the La Sal Mountains. This trail begins where Miner's Basin Road ends. You can access the Miner's Basin mining area near the middle of the trail. There was copper discovered at the location, and it was mined back in the late 1800s. After leaving Miner's Basin, the trail turns in a southwesterly direction passing by Gold Knob and tracking through pine forests and large groves of aspen. The trail ends on Warner Lake Road just a short distance from the scenic Warner Lake and the Hazzard County trailhead.

Starting from the Red Canyon Campground, the Buckhorn Trail climbs steadily through the scenic red rock terrain, taking hikers to a vantage point overlooking Red Canyon. At approximately 3/4 of a mile into the hike, the trail comes to a junction with the Golden Wall Trail #33095. Stay to the right to continue on the Buckhorn Trail to its endpoint.

This trail leads you around a smaller basin on the west side of Kodachrome Basin State Park. The highlight of this trail is Cool Cave. The basin is surrounded by impressive rock formations, which are easy to admire as the trail gently ascends up and down the sandy slopes.
No services for over 50 miles!

Lichen It is the climbing trail from the southwest trailhead. That also makes it the first half of a Lava Flow Loop. If you feel like a heading up a sustained climb, the trail can pass by pretty quickly. It's very smooth and the conditions are great for hiking.
Park at the Deer Creek Dam Trailhead. Trail departs from the parking lot.
Watch for rattle snakes and steer clear of private property.

The lake this trail gets its name from is the first one and only an easy half mile in. Between this lake and the next one, Shepard Lake, the trail is a bit rougher and has a bit of elevation loss. After this lake the trail is not as rough to the last two lakes, Hoover and Maba. There is also road access to these lakes, so you may see some people car camping here.

From the bridge that crosses Little Cottonwood Creek near the White Pine Lake Trailhead, go to your left (to the east), away from the main trail. The small singletrack trail splits off and immediately starts climbing alongside the creek for a short distance, and then starts ascending away from the creek. The trail goes over a couple of rocky and rooty sections and crosses a few small creek crossings (most have small foot bridges over them) but is often smooth and easy going. The trail transitions from forest to fields (of wildflowers, in season) as it gets closer to Snowbird and the views of Cottonwood Ridge are outstanding. This trail allows users to connect to many trails in the Snowbird area.

The Pleasant Creek trail follows a hiker-made route through a pretty canyon. The perennial stream must be crossed many times — usually by hopping from rock to rock. The route also traverses long sandy benches and navigates through vegetation at water's edge. An optional diversion to a good slot canyon is detailed below.

The trail heads northeast, away from the parking area and runs through a transition zone above the creek. At one third-of-a-mile, it drops toward the stream for the first crossing. As with many of the crossings, determining the best rocks to use while hopping across the stream may require a little study. A less obvious path heads up the flat ledge on the other side to join an old road. Ahead, a dense stand of big sage appears right before the trail rounds a point around the southern wall.

The second stream crossing leads to a long sandy bench that can be a spectacular flower garden during a wet spring. After this pleasant stroll, the crossings occur more frequently, and some routes are easier and more obvious than others. While there are a couple of spots where low water levels or recent deposition may change the number of crossings, usually there will be 16 required to get to the east park boundary.

At the sixth crossing, a huge Navajo dome patterned with heavily eroded fractures looms on the right side of the canyon. The canyon becomes less wide at the next ford, and after two more crossings, Pleasant Creek runs through an interesting sluice in the bedrock.

Around the 2.4 mile mark the sheer wall on the south side ends, and a large sand flat extends further south. A nice optional diversion is possible if you re-cross the creek to the right and follow a visible hiker-made path to a wash leading from an opening in the Navajo Sandstone. This part of the canyon has a couple of good slot sections for hikers to explore before turning around at a large chockstone near the end of the slot. Several obstacles are present and pools of water can be found during wet times.

Back on the main trail; two more crossings proceed a climb up a sandy slope to a gap in the neck of a tight meander. The trail quickly descends back to the creek from there. The canyon walls begin to lower after this point, and the stream follows a more direct path. The trail comes to an end at a fence that crosses the creek near the east boundary of the park. From this point, retrace your steps 3.8 miles back to the parking area.

This content was contributed by author Rick Stinchfield. For a comprehensive hiking guide to Capitol Reef National Park and to see more by Rick, click here.

Sovereign is the main artery trail of the Sovereign Trail System.  It runs from Willow Springs Road to the southern edge of Cedar Mountain.

The slickrock and singletrack trail begins at a junction with Pipeline coming from Willow Springs Road. You'll hike over numerous fields of slick rock interspersed with sections singletrack. There's climbing, descending and level trail along the way. 

From the start of Sovereign to the first intersection with Salt Wash the trail climbs gradually. From there through the third intersection, the route goes up and down and across multiple expanses of rock and dry, dusty washes. At the fourth intersection to the Salt Wash trail (L4 Sovereign Connect) you'll be faced with a steady climb. After passing L5 Sovereign Connect, the trail meets at the terminus of Salt Wash.  Stay left here to descend down towards Dalton Wells Road. 

At the bottom, continue on the Sovereign trail straight into the wash and will now head towards and skirt the southern base of Cedar Mountain. The trail climbs and levels out as it intersects with Long Valley Road.  Afterwards Sovereign descends slightly just before a stiff ascent up to the rim of Cedar Mountain.  

Once the real climbing starts you'll be greeted by slightly more technical and narrow singletrack. At the junction with Cedar Mountain stay left.  The trail continues to climb to the rim going west where it skirts the edge.  The section of Sovereign is a bit more loose and chossy than what you'll experience on the lower reaches of the trail.

Sovereign ends at an intersection with Brush Basin trail, a descent to the outer Sovereign trailhead on Dalton Wells Road near Hwy 191.

Alternatively, you can bear right at the intersection to stay on the Sovereign - Cedar Mountain Loop.
This may be both muddy after rain and difficult to navigate in winter.

The Surprise Canyon Trail begins by quickly crossing the wide and flat Halls Creek drainage. On the approach, the trail enters and exits a wash a number of times before reaching the mouth of the canyon.

For the remainder of the hike, the route will stay on the bottom of the canyon, sometimes on rock, but mostly on sand. A little ways ahead, the canyon begins a series of curves and becomes very deep. The walls rise hundreds of feet above and are decorated with dramatic desert varnish. A recent rockfall has dropped a pretty banded sandstone into the wash just after the bends in the canyon start. A small pour-off and rock jam are easily passed.

The canyon remains impressive and easy to navigate up to an undercut and chockstone. This obstacle can be bypassed by retreating 100 feet down canyon and finding a user-made bypass on the south side. This steep, loose climb drops easily back in the canyon which soon ends in a rubble slope.

Since the canyon beyond the bypass is not quite as interesting as that below, the undercut in the main wash is probably a good point to turn around for most. The return trip changes the light and offers different aspects along the way, and, like most Capitol Reef canyons, the way out is just as good as the way in.

This content was contributed by author Rick Stinchfield. For a comprehensive hiking guide to Capitol Reef National Park and to see more by Rick, click here.

Starting from the North Old Ranch Road parking lot, head east on this climbing, descending, climbing, then undulating trail. Rambler does just that, rambles through some very varied sections.

Heading west to east the trail climbs past Rambler DT, through a very difficult rocky and loose section to an intersection with Rademan Ridge. From the ridge, continue east on a rugged downhill to the Round Valley Express. The next section of Rambler continues east and climbs a serpentine track on tacky dirt, past Seventy 101 and ends at a four-way intersection with Nowhere Elks and Rusty Shovel.

From this four-way intersection continue east and descend the best part of Rambler yet! Crush past the intersections with High Side and Karis as the trail winds its way down to the eastern slope of Round Valley.

The final portion of Rambler take you smoothly along the hillside as bench cut singletrack. Bypass Ramble On, Karis, and stay left at Practice Loops. Eventually the trail crosses Ability Way, Fairway Hills Connector, and terminates at Hat Trick on a small climb.
Pull off the Moki Dugout Road and hike to the lookout point. It is well worth the views of Valley of the Gods and out toward Monument Valley.

The Utah Trust Lands Singletrack is a hiking trail that begins from La Sal Pass Rd and winds through the Utah Trust Lands to Geyser Pass Road. There are stunning views looking eastward towards Colorado and westward to Mt. Peale in the La Sal Range.

This trail completes the access to the Grizzly Ridge Yurt in the Ashley National Forest. The dirt road is clear and well marked with blue diamonds that are used by cross-country skiing and snowshoeing visitors in the winter. There are some great views of the Red Fleet Reservoir and distant Vernal from the top.

The yurt remains locked unless being occupied by guests. It's available for reservations all months except November, April, and May. To find out more about reserving this primitive yurt click here.

The trailhead is just off the side of Ridgedale Drive, and is well-marked. There is no parking lot, but you can park on either side of the road.

trail_name: Great Western Trail: Parleys to Sheep Canyon
description: Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office
Starting at the Mud Lake Trailhead, go around the south end of the lake until the trail connects with Blue Lake Trail #172.
This is the primary connector, from Kimball Jct, for hiking the Glenwild Loop, Flying Dog, and the trails in Bob's Basin.  There aren't any technical features to speak of - just smooth.
This is a variation of the Phipps Wash Route that can be used to create a loop with the Phipps Wash Route. The trail is very scenic and serene.

If you take a commercial shuttle, you'll start this hike from Geyser Pass, as mapped. If you are shuttling yourself, you can start lower: at Oowah Lake, at the Geyser Pass parking area, at the pass, or further up the Burro Pass road, depending on your vehicle and energy level.

The route from Geyser Pass (named for an early settler, not an actual water spout) works upward to Burro Pass at about 11,150-ft. Along the way you'll hike jeep trails and singletrack, this is a steep trail though!

From the pass, the trail drops precipitously down through evergreen forest, sharp switchbacks, black dirt, igneous rocks and roots. This is a difficult, and rugged trail, in a way that is out of character with most of Moab. Eventually, you reach jeep road again and continue left, then up and down in aspen glades. If you are lucky, you'll be here in the fall when the trees are gold and luminous. 

Watch for trail signs toward Warner Lake to show you the right way. Either rejoin the LaSal Mountain Loop Road, or Hazzard County trail to continue The Whole Enchilada.
Parking at the trailhead is free and plentiful. The trailhead is easy to find as there is a huge gateway to mark the start of the trail.

A long singletrack trail hiking following Dry Fork through sagebrush and riparian and conifer forests. Multiple trailheads allow multiple hiking options.


Looks like this trail could use some love! If you know it, add some more to the description.
On summer weekends parking is limited at Albion Basin Campground, so may require riding up from base of Alta Ski Resort.
Restrooms and water are at the park.

This is an uphill-only for mountain bikers, so if you're on foot, you don't have to worry about cyclists coming down quickly, making for a much more relaxing outing. The grades are also a bit easier to manage than the neighboring Creek View Trail, so if you're hoping for an easier start, this trail is a great alternative.

Use this trail as an out and back or to complete a loop can use it as an out and back on its own, or complete a longer hike on the North Rim of Gooseberry Mesa. No matter how far you go, you'll enjoy spectacular vistas of Zion National Park across the Virgin River Valley.

This trail traverses the face of the La Sals. It travels through aspen stands with outstanding views back towards Moab and Canyonlands National Park. The trail is not super technical and can be hikeed in either direction, but this is certainly the recommended direction.

It begins with a descent into Brumley Creek. The last 1/4 mile into the creek is very steep and then you'll have a steep 1/4-mile climb back out of the drainage. The trail will then mellow out as you climb towards the highpoint. Once you hit the switchbacks, the trail becomes steep again before gaining a high point on the trail. You'll traverse with a quick 1/4-mile descent before going back to the same contour. After the second highpoint, you'll begin a steep downhill to the La Sal Pass Rd. When the trail becomes really steep look for Squaw Springs. This is a nice stop used by some of the early settlers to the area.
To get to the parking lot, there is a $6 entrance fee to get into American Fork Canyon.

This loop literally has a mix of everything. Slickrock to sand, forest to grassy fields and possibly even a water crossing or two during a heavy rain. Seldom flat and never in a straight line, the trail winds its way around a large basin west of UT 313. The route drops down several rock shelves and across a couple different drainages before a meandering climb back up the other side - regardless of which direction you choose to hike it.

It’s hard not to stop and admire the amazing rock-work that went into the construction of this trail by the builders as you hike certain sections. The same can be said about the natural scenery in this area, the trail itself is technical enough to demand a continuous level of attention on your footing.

Because of the constantly changing trail and overall length, this trail by itself will be a challenge for some. But by beginning and ending on the Chisholm Trail, this loop can be easily integrated with other trails in the area for a much longer hike for anyone wanting to do so.

Starting at Nebo Creek Road, the Blackhawk Trail ascends up a moderately steep slope before leveling off to rolling topography. The trail winds through open meadows and shaded woodlands and offers beautiful views of the surrounding mountains. This is a popular multi-use trail.

The Blackhawk trail forms the backbone of a network of trails along the Mount Nebo National Scenic Byway. Most use occurs at the northern end of the trail; at times the southern end can be difficult to follow.

From Gambel Oak, the trail quickly descends the east side of April Mountain utilizing multiple switchbacks. It is useful as a connector trail to access Gambel Oak but not especially exciting on its own.

From the ridge where the Logan Dry Canyon trail ends and this trail begins, the trail starts to descend down towards Logan Canyon. 

The trail then turns back to the southeast and then starts to cross a series of drainages and avalanche paths in the northern shadow of Logan Peak. The avalanche paths are of particular interest with the steep cliffs and gullies above and the talus underfoot. In the middle of one of the avalanche paths there is a roughly made sign that shows a small path off to a spring to the left (north) which is a short jaunt off of the path for some water if you've run out. 

After this sign, the trail goes up some switchbacks as it ascends up and around a small ridge. The trail continues to undulate but gradually ascends as it crosses these drainages and heads toward the Inspiration Point Road FR 126. 

Eventually the trail enters a dense forest, and as it passes through this forest it crosses a final, more shallowly sloping drainage that has a faint trail going off to the right. The actual Logan Dry-Mill Hollow trail continues to the left and ends up meeting up with the Inspiration Point Road FR 126, where the trail ends.

This mostly contouring, bench cut trail starts at Jeremy Road and makes its way through the heart of the Glenwild Area Trails to Stealth Trail. Though sun-exposed and almost always hot, using this trail is a necessity when navigating to/from Flying Dog and/or Bob's Basin. Be sure to bring a lot of water.

If you like hiking through thick stands of sagebrush and some intermittent trees on tight singletrack, 24-7 is the trail for you. There are generally many other users in this area.

Access from Warner Lake Campground is by Forest Trail #033 (Warner Lake/Beaver Basin) for 0.23 miles before reaching the intersection and start of this trail. This trail then continues downhill through aspen stands to Forest Road #076 (Oowah Lake) and Oowah Lake Campground.  

Most visitors prefer to travel from Warner Lake Campground to Oowah Lake Campground (downhill). This popular trail sees use by multiple different types of users. Primarily it sees hikers, mountain bikers, and equestrian users. Please respect one another and observe standard trail etiquette: mountain bikers yield to both hikers and equestrian users and hikers yield to equestrian users.
Land Manager:  USFS - Fishlake National Forest Office

From the Crystal Lake Trailhead, this trail will take you past a number of small lakes on the way to Clyde Lake and then on to the Notch Mountain Trail #81. There are a few short stretches where the trail is rather rocky, but they’re not too challenging, so bring the kids. From Clyde Lake, the trail continues northeast along the shore and passes Twin Lakes shortly before ending at Notch Mountain Trail #81.

The Chisholm Trail is a connector route between the Navajo Rocks and Horsethief trail systems. Expect two-way traffic along this route. This description assumes a start at the north end where it begins on the Big Lonely trail 50 yards west of UT313. 

The first mile is a twisty route across an open meadow, a dirt road and cattle guard before gradually starting up into the pinion pines. Once in the trees, the trail constantly transitions between rock and hard pack, working its way out along the edges of the canyons whenever possible. Even heading uphill the trail maintains a nice grade and never seems to climb for too long or be overly steep.

At roughly five miles, the trail nears the Horsethief Campground, and then crosses the dirt access road. A small parking area and map/info kiosk is here. Shortly after is another route into the campground and the Rowdy trail. From the Campground, the Chisholm Trail can be accessed via two short trails; one directly across from the main entrance and the second at campsite #50 which is also conveniently close to a restroom. 

Continuing on the Chisholm Trail is made up of the same terrain but on more of an even elevation for the next 1.5 miles to where it crosses UT313. Here is another parking area with a map/info kiosk. The trail then makes a quick descent to where it terminates at the intersection with the Mustang Loop.

This short trail originates at the Geyser Pass drop-point, behind the pit toilet. Follow it across a meadow as it ascends gradually and then enjoy a short descent through aspens and more meadows. Eventually, you'll hit the dirt road where you'll turn left and begin the ascent to Burro Pass.
Parking at UOP is free.
No restrooms at the trailhead and the parking area is small. The parking is shared with the Wheeler Creek - East Fork Trail which  loops below. It could be fun to link up the two trail systems.

This is a easy, but often loose, trail that loops back to the Beaclaw Poppy descent.  This is another roller coaster trail.

Start from the junction with Stucki Connector and head south on the trail. the trail begins with a  climb, but the grade is gentle. As you reach the ridge, and the junction with at trail coming in from the right, stay left and the trail will begin to descend. The trail ends at the junction with Bloomington Micro Loop.
Great trailhead parking by Electric Lake off Highway 31.

A more interesting, but similar to Needles, way down from Needles Lodge. Excellent scenery through dozens of switchbacks on a mostly hard packed surface with occasional rocky section, loose rocks, and roots.

Follow the signs at several confluences and watch for traffic in both directions.  This trail may be a better option for descending than Needles. There are a number of stream crossings in early spring.

Goosebump follows the contours of the mesa rising above you. The views are most excellent. The trail itself is pretty much a roller coaster, with short little climbs followed by short quick descents, over and over again. 

In several places, the trail will split into a Blue and Green section. The Blues can be a bit rugged. The green sections on the other hand are also quite fun and feature very nice smooth up/downs.

Eventually, the fun has to come to an end and Goosebumps finishes at a junction with several jeep/atv trails.

There is a large parking lot on the south end of the trail at Jensen Nature Park. There is a small lot at the north end of the trail on 1300 North. There are a few parks along the trail that also have parking lots.

The Blue Lake Trail branches off from the Naturalist Basin Trail #084  about 1 mile from its junction with the Uinta Highline Trail. It passes between the Morat Lakes before climbing a steep bench which contains Blue Lake. 

Blue Lake has room for camping but very few trees of any size (they're mostly dwarf pines). Mt. Agassiz forms a stunning backdrop to this lake.

To access this trail, you have to hike around two miles from either parking lot at the south or north end. Be aware as driving northbound is permitted on the gravel Bar M going to the north. Head through a gate (close it behind you) and find a parking spot where the doubletrack bends to the right.

This trail doesn't have a lot of elevation change. The northern end is ~100 ft lower than the southern end, but you'll end up accumulating another 100 vertical feet of climbing as you head through the Courthouse Wash. That said, the slope is very gradual save for a section of the wall itself which can be loose.

There is a spring around the mid-point of the trail, in a large meadow.

The Precipice Trail starts on the left about 50 feet from the trailhead stepover off the Barrel Roll Trail. It connects to the Sidewinder Trail and can provide an alternative route for the lower section of Barrel Roll. Although it sits just below Barrel Roll, Precipice offers different terrain, plants, and views. 

Precipice is so named because of the tight squeeze that occurs in the middle section of the trail. Huge rocks slabs tumble down the slope from the upper rim and pinch the trail against a lower cliff edge. While trail construction has moderated the technical aspects of the trail, exposure is still a factor.

From the parking area by the second gate, the road starts to ascend through a sparsely populated conifer forest. After about a half mile, the road ends at the Cache Valley Archery range (which is only open to members of the archery association, not just anyone who wants to go). 

Instead of going to the range, go to the left where the road crosses a small drainage where there is a sign that points to the left saying "Card Canyon East 064" and to the right saying "Card Canyon West." Take the fork to the right and the trail starts to slowly ascend by a dry creek bed. It continues through a varying forest with conifers, scrub oak, and some aspens at times. This can be a really gorgeous part in the fall as the colors are changing. 

Eventually, the trail starts to ascend more steeply through some rocky portions, and then it starts to switchback up onto the hillside above the drainage, which allows for some views of the cliff bands on the western side of the canyon, which are impressive. Eventually, the trail starts to level off as it reaches the meadow that sits above the canyon (which can be filled with beautiful wildflowers in the spring) and eventually meets up with a dirt road, and another sign.

Head north from Chesler Park on the sandy trail towards the needles rising majestically right in front of you. Reach the base of the needles after a third of a mile at the bottom of a boulder covered cleft between two massive needles. Once you make your way up, you get rewarded with amazing views of Devils Kitchen and you can even see the Island in the Sky in the far with its prominent Junction Butte and Grand View Point.

Continue down to the flat but narrow stretch of prairie framed on the left by what is known as the Devils Pocket. The sandy trail is oftentimes almost a foot deep. You pass the DP1 camp site at about 1.2 miles, but it's fairly well hidden and there are no signs. Reach Devils Kitchen after 1.6 miles.

trail_name: South Fork of Little Deer Creek Trail #252
description: The South Fork of Little Deer Creek Trail #242 is an enjoyable trail that travels from the Summit TH to the Ridge Trail #157.  This trail links several loop routes that can be used to visit different areas around Pleasant Grove Ranger District.  The trail moves through aspens, firs, and open meadows, with views of Mount Timpanogos along the way.  A reroute in the vicinity of the Cascade Spring road was recently performed to aid the sustainability of the trail, and users should follow the new route as the old route is now closed.

Deadman's Ridge Trail is found on the southern end of the Bar M trails, connecting to Lazy and EZ to the north and Long Branch and Bar-B to the south.

From the Moab Canyon Paved Path, access to Deadman's Ridge starts on a doubletrack across from Rusty Spur.  Hike west, climbing a bit and winding around to the start of the trail which will be to your right.

The initial climb to get on the lower ridge is not steep and rolls along singletrack and slickrock.  The route ramps up a bit from here, climbing steadily to a high point on the trail.  It's worth taking a break here to enjoy the 360 degree views, including an incredible look into Arches National Park.

The route from here climbs and descends several times to the Bar-B intersection.  The grades aren't steep but the trail has lots of up-and-over rocks.  Stay right at the Bar-B intersection to continue on Deadman's.

After another down and up, Deadman's Ridge Trail intersects Bar-B again.  From here there's a rare smooth section descending to Long Branch.  Stay right to finish the trail with a descent to the Moab Canyon Paved Path.

The trail begins at a parking lot off of State Route 32. You go through two gates to get to the actual trail. This trail passes through private land. The trail itself is open to the public, but any area off trail is private property and ought to be respected to ensure access to future users. 

The trail begins with some switchbacks, climbing to the top of ledge. The trail then follows the ledge for a ways and then climbs again. After several more switchbacks and some movement into and out of a few small gulches, you climb once more to reach the summit of Rocky Top. 

The top has several large boulders and provides great views of Kamas Valley, the back of the Wasatch Range, the west side of the Uintas, and much more. The climb is gradual enough that the running is great. This trail is mixed use, so you'll likely see bikes, horses, hikers, and runners. Weekends there is more traffic.

Start uphill with a lot of rolling rock ribs, generously marked with green paint. There are a few short downhill sections, but it generally climbs at a low angle. 

After a mile of mixed singletrack and slickrock, you'll encounter an enormous swath of slickrock and some bumpy trail for a little while.  Continue on a mix of dirt singletrack and short patches of rock that takes you to the top of the bluff for a great view over the Salt Valley and Arches National Park beyond.

Hike relatively flat trail along the top of this plateau on much easier dirt singletrack with nice swoops until you intersect Baby Steps North and Baby Steps Loop.
Land Manager:  Farmington Parks & Rec

This singletrack trail spurs off of the Bonneville Shoreline Trail: Green Canyon to Logan. The trail meanders through sagebrush and over some hills, offering a little more excitement and challenge than the BST doubletrack. The trail can be accessed near the electrical substation at the bottom of green canyon or near the picnic area along the Bonneville Shoreline Trail: Green Canyon to Logan.

The preferred direction is north to south - you'll be going more downhill in this direction.

This trail is nonstop bumps and small ledges on almost 100% slickrock. 
You'll wind in and out and up and down a lot, and all the bumps can get tiring.  Despite no major climbs, you're hardly ever hiking flat terrain.  

It's marked very well, and the orange paint usually indicates the easiest line.

This is an easier black diamond trail suitable for most intermediates willing to dismount occasionally, and it's possible to bail out at many points and head down to Dino-Flow (much easier) or to Copper Ridge 4x4 (very easy).

You can make a great loop by starting at the south parking area,hiking up Dino-Flow and back on EKG.

The trail begins at an intersection with Griffin Point Trail #38. From there, it descends north, then east, very steeply towards White Creek. Winding through tight trees and some open meadows, be sure to follow the cairns and blazes to stay on track.

Once at White Creek, the trail descends at a much more pleasant rate. There's one creek crossing that you'll encounter, but nothing too severe.

From the sign that indicates the two forks of Card Canyon, take the left fork. It starts off by gradually ascending past a small picnic area, and then enters a sparsely populated forest. 
The trail has some fun, short rocky sections as it ascends as it follows the canyon bottom. Eventually it reaches a short switchback where the trail leaves the bottom of the canyon and starts to parallel it from up above, and has some short, fun downhill sections mixed in with the ascent. 

After a little over a half a mile from the starting point, there is a really spectacular rock thumb jutting up, right by the trail, off to the left (as you are going up). This is definitely one of the highlights of this trail. Soon after passing the rock thumb, the trail switches back and ascends into the meadow that houses the ponds that are surrounded by bluebells in spring. Keep an eye on the trail as you go past the ponds, and then the trail becomes distinct again as it starts to ascend steeply, over fallen trees and through an aspen grove until it emerges into a clearing, and then onto the Adams Corral Road.

Section 3 follows the east shore before doing a big climb to the ridge above the lake. If you are doing this trail at the end of the summer, make sure to enjoy the wild raspberries growing on the hillside as you do the climb.

There are two road accesses on the east side of the lake. They are rough roads suitable only for high clearance 4x4 vehicles.

Arth's Corner is another stellar section of trail in the Mag 7 network.  

It connects Getaway to Little Canyon or can be part of a loop with Great Escape.

From the 3-way intersection with Getaway and Great Escape, Arth's Corner gradually descends over the red dirt and slickrock characteristic of the area.

The trail is a branch from the well-known Highline trail. Starting at the western terminal of the Highline trail at Hayden Pass, you follow the Highline trail east about 5 1/2 miles to a junction with the Naturalist Basin trail. 

Follow this trail northeast about 2 1/2 miles to Jordan Lake. The trail continues on past Jordan Lake to Shaler Lake, but Shaler Lake has few trees making it less desirable for camping. From Jordan Lake you can investigate the much of the surrounding area including Blue Lake to the west.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

The parking lot is located 12.2 miles west of Vernal, UT, halfway past MM 129. There is a dirt road on the north side of the road where it will take you to a small dirt parking lot. Last time I went, there was a wheel nailed to the fence just before the parking lot.

This is a very typical trail on the orange-red dirt of the area.

Connects Corner Canyon from Jacob's Ladder area to the Alpine system below Suncrest. Can be ridden up or down from or to Hog Hollow Road. Clean and moderate grades through scrub oak with some nice valley views.

This is the original Red Fleet trail. Start from the dirt parking area 0.6 miles from US 191. 

The trail immediately starts on a singletrack downhill. Cross the wash on the culvert, head along the fence and up the bottom. At the junction, follow signs to the left to begin the first climb. 

Once at the top, you'll swing right into another short, downhill section. At the bottom of the hill, head left to continue up a small valley. 

After a couple of wash crossings, you'll see another sign directing you left to the second climb. At the top of this hill, continue left through a juniper section which takes you to the BLM-Simplot boundary. The trail continues along the fence line in a roller coaster segment of short ups and downs. 

As you leave the boundary line, you enter the "Jazz Gets Down" downhill.

At the bottom of the hill, make a sharp right turn to continue on JCM back to the parking area. You'll climb out of the wash to a doubletrack, where the trail crosses and continues to a water trough. From there, head left for a long, low angle descent. 

At the next water trough, bear right to a short downhill where you head back into the valley and eventually start back on the trail the way you came. After following the fence line and Hwy. 191,  you'll cross a wash culvert/cattle guard and start heading up hill. At the bermed turn heading left, watch for the blast warning sign and a faint trail heading down to the paved road. 

Please climb back to the TH on this road to avoid downhill traffic coming down the trail.

The road to the top is rough. Though I saw one non-AWD/4WD get to the top, I would have liked to have beheld that, as well as him getting back down. Ignore all the signs from the homeowners who don't want people to use that access road. It is BLM at the top (with amazing distributed camp sites) and the access road is 100% ok for anyone to use.

The Sipapu Overlook Trail is a great way to view the largest bridge in the National Monument without too much of a workout. Sipapu is also the second largest natural bridge in the US. From the parking area, take the Sipapu Trail which descends some slickrock slabs with steps cut out to ease the walk.  Traverse west along the wide rock bench, keeping back from the edge.  This is a neat spot to peer across the canyon rim.  After a series of steel stairs, you must climb down a short log ladder to get over a cliff band.  

Continue along the cliff under a shady stretch of trail that is overhung by sheer rock.  Up ahead you can see people traveling along a nearly level and very picturesque walkway of rock.  These unique features of the trail make it memorable even for frequent desert visitors.  The Sipapu Trail to the canyon bottom branches off to the right, but keep going straight for the Overlook Trail. Arrive at an exposed spit of rock that juts out into the canyon, look down and to your left to see Sipapu Bridge itself. Retrace your steps back to the parking lot once you've finished marveling at Mother Nature's handiwork.

As the park's brochures and info boards explain, natural bridges are created differently than arches.  Bridges are formed by and span streams of flowing water.  Arches are formed by weather-powered erosion or pounding waves.

This trail is a groomed singletrack that gives hikers access to Eagle Crest Trail from the base of Levitate Downhill, Vertigo Downhill, and parking on Brookside Drive. South Maple Hollow Trail provides access to the west. 

Woodshollow is newly constructed and is wide enough for bypassing others, but do keep an eye out for other trail users. The trail is a rolling climb or descent based on the direction of travel and is great for beginners and intermediate hikers. This is a south-facing trail and is the first to warm up during the chilly season and is the first to dry out after a rain.

This is a short trail that allows visitors to Squaw Basin a chance to climb out of the basin and view the surrounding country. To the north Brown Duck Mountain, Cleveland Peak and Squaw Peak as well as all of Squaw Basin are visible from its summit. To the west are Tworoose, Kidney and Island lakes.
This trail is open to high clearance vehicles and ATVs.
Land Manager:  Farmington Parks & Rec

Slippery When Wet is a 5 mile lariat hike that starts at the main parking area. There is a trail junction with Retail Sale  shortly after crossing the road. The trail intersects with Retail Sale again at about 0.3 miles then shortly splits to form the loop. There are some nice scenic overlooks on this trail.

trail_name: Utah Public Lands Singletrack - Dark Canyon
description: Another section of Utah Trust Lands Singletrack.
Section 4 continues along the ridge before dropping back to the shore around the south end of the lake. Enjoy the beaver dams in the lake on the south end.

From the fork in the trails right after the bridge across White Pine Creek, go either to the left or straight to get into this pleasant, short loop. It winds through small forests and sagebrush meadows, which allows for great views of the mountains (Gog and Magog) around and the cirque behind White Pine Lake. There also is the possibility of seeing deer or moose if you come early enough in the morning. Just being up in this gorgeous alpine environment is reward enough for the short jaunt around the loop.

Rim Ramble splits from Rim Rock 1.2 miles into that hike. Combine this trail with Rim Reaper for a singletrack climb and/or descent that is way more fun than the section of Rim Rock it bypasses. This trail is all singletrack with good switchbacks, and a few short rougher sections. The trail is mostly a firm coarse sandy soil with large rounded rocks.  It can be done both directions.
This is a fun singletrack loop that goes around a section of wildland/urban interface. New development abounds here, but that development has brought in new trail construction as well.

This trail isn't super trilling and it doesn't look like much, but it's surprisingly fun.

This smooth trail winds around a Martian landscape of harsh red rocks with little vegetation.  You'll climb up and down little mesas, but the climbs are never long or steep, and everything is smooth.  The views of the La Sals are outstanding.

Check out Klondike Bluff Beginner Loop for a longer option.

The entire trail is lined with rocks and you can't get lost.
Land Manager:  Basin Recreation

From Tanner Hollow - Big John #058 this singletrack travels through the trees until you get to the amazing views at Bosman Ridge. From there, you'll descend left into some burned forest and eventually through a large open meadow.  At the meadow, just keep making your way south downhill on the left side. The trail disappears at times until you get back into the trees at Jimmy Reed Creek - Bosman #064.

Short trail but a great way to extend your outing in the area or connect to the neighborhood.  Huge views of the Salt Lake Valley and pleasant oak groves near the top.  The trail is smooth and never too steep.

The trail starts from a picnic area and climbs, slowly in a drainage at first. It soon climbs out to a ridge for rather better views. It rounds into a series of rock outcrops that is rather like a small canyon before coming out again at the top for excellent views of the canyon painted in reds and yellows.

McCoy Flats' signature trail. Retail Sale features smooth singletrack with a few mountain biking features.

The trail has a few good climbs and descents and is otherwise rolling and fun.

This trail cuts off of the Jackalope trail about 3/4 of the way up the climb. It is well signed and easy to find. The trail starts with sweeping turns that criss-cross back and forth across the gully. As it descends the radius of the turns begin to straighten and the slope begins to mellow slightly.

As it comes to the bottom of the wash there is a short mellow climb up and over the small ridge and down into the next wash where the trail continues. From here the trail is short and easy to follow. It just goes down the wash until it meets back up with the Jackalope trail. From there you can continue straight to the Serendipity flat trail section, or you can make a right back onto the Jackalope trail and continue on down and back to the trailhead.

Lime allows users to complete one big loop by using other trails. This trail has a fair amount slickrock and rugged sections. Pay attention to the rock cairns.

The views of West Temple and Mount Kinesava are breathtaking. If you are lucky you might catch a glimpse of a California Condor floating overhead.

The Whirlwind Loop is a fun 2 mile loop best done clockwise from where it starts at the Mustang Loop. This downhill route runs along the contours of a canyon traversing quickly between rock ledges, drops and hairpin corners. At the bottom, a left turn will take you 0.2 miles to the 7-Up Trail and a right will lead up a fun climb back to an intersection of the Wildcat and Mustang Loop trails.

The trails in this system reflect the rugged and challenging terrain they are built within. Tight corners, constant grade changes are present. Surfaces vary from hard pack to slickrock to a bit of sand as the trail winds its way through pinion pines and rock canyons, all the while delivering unparalleled views of the majestic Moab area.
Land Manager:  Logan City, UT - Parks and Recreation

Pick up a brochure at the parking area an proceed along the numbered stops. (The brochure can also be downloaded from here.) The trail first climbs to some views, then circles around. The much longer Fishlake Trail starts at the top of the loop for anyone wanting a much larger hike. When the loop rejoins, there is still 0.3 miles to return to the beginning.

Rim Ramble splits from Rim Rock 1.6 miles into that hike. Combine this loop trail with Rim Rock Trail for more sweet singletrack and great vistas. The trail is firm coarse sandy soil with large rounded rocks.

When used in conjunction with connecting trails, the Big Lonely becomes a section of the greater Navajo Rocks Chaco Loop, an alternate route to the 7-Up Trail or part of the route joining the Navajo Rocks to Horsethief areas via the Chisholm Trail.

The trail itself is a short, mellow hike. Starting at its junction with the Big Mesa Trail, the trail quickly climbs up into the pinions mixed with slickrock patches. A huge expanse of slickrock on the north-facing slope is a fun distraction from the climb, just be mindful of the edge. 

The trail across the slickrock here isn’t always slick - it’s rather rough. Once on top, the trail evens out a bit to and across UT313 and another half mile until it ends at the Coney Island Trail.

Departing from North 40 just north of the O to 40 Linkup, Maverick snakes down through berm turns as it winds its way toward the parking area. The trail ends back at North 40, 0.4 miles north of its trailhead.

This trail was designed to make a more interesting finish to hikes on Circle-O. From the end of Circle-O, just take the O to 40 Linkup, hike a few yards up North-40 to the start of Maverick, then head back to the parking area.

This easier trail connects the west end of Houdini Trail to The Edge Trail just south of the Willow Springs (Arches Loop) doubletrack. It's primarily used for quick access to Redhot. 

Look for the light purple markings.

If you've gone as far as Eddie's Flat via the Eddie's Flat Trail, then you might as well continue on up to Eddie's Peak. Look for the trail in the south-east corner of the flat. Follow it to the peak, which is along the north ridge of Bair Canyon.  

Sadly, there is no clear trail, if any, from Eddie's Peak going along the ridge and up to the Great Wester Trail, although I wouldn't be surprised if you picked up a faint trail along the way. The satellite imagery clearly indicates a trail, but you'll have to bush-whack from Eddie's Peak to find it.

Note that also from the flat, there is another trail (hard to follow) heading north toward Holmes Creek.  It doesn't go as far as the creek, as far as I'm aware, but it does reach an old campsite.

This is a good option to ascend the Klondike area trails: it's a steady climb with some small ledges, but it's never too hard.  There are short sections of dirt but it's mostly slickrock.

The trail is well marked with blue paint.

This is a fun variation to the Flying Dog descent and can make a more manageable hike depending on where you start. This segment is a great climb and even better descent with fun switchbacks and beautiful scenery.
Alternate trail to Rattlesnake Gulch Trail with more gradual climb and many switchbacks. This trail is a bit more exposed than Rattlesnake Gulch.

Blazing Saddle is a nice little singletrack that incorporates a lot of switchbacks to make for either a fun descent or a manageable climb to/from Wasatch Crest—overall a much better alternative to Thaynes Road in either direction.

From the top of the Crescent Lift, take 3 Candles to Keystone Trail to Shadow Lake Trail to Blazing Saddle for a technically easy, aerobically satisfying, abbreviated climb to Wasatch Crest.

Borderline runs along the southern and eastern portions of the Klonzo trail system, connecting with most of the trails.

From the lower parking area, Borderline provides access to Dunestone, Boondocks and the Klonzo - Lower Loop.

From the upper parking area, the trail connects with Cross Canyon, Secret Passage and Wahoo.

The trail is rolling and smooth with little climbing between the two parking areas.  From the upper parking area to Wahoo, Borderline is best done downhill to maximize the fun.

Starting from Klonzo parking area, hike up Borderline to access Zoltar. The trail runs through the slickrock and brush to the southeast and takes you to Houdini, Red Hot and several other excellent trails in the Klonzo South area.

It has no appreciable change in elevation and makes for a great, mildly technical connection between the two Klonzo areas. This could easily be done either direction.

The Dunestone trail is just that; a link up of petrified dunes all stuck in perfect waves.  The trail is a loop that can be done in either direction or part of other loops in the Klonzo system. 

Dunestone stays up on the mesa above the lower Klonzo parking area and connects easily to Boondocks.  The trail is generally smooth, but can be rougher at times negotiating all the bits of slickrock.

This is a well-maintained paved path that runs around Wellsville Reservoir. The views of the Wellsville Mountains are incredible from this reservoir. It is a popular spot for fishing. There are also plenty of ducks. The park has a large playground, a baseball diamond, and lots of open grass.

VertiGo can be accessed via Wahoo, using Cross Canyon, or Gravitron. It has lots of exposure hence its name. Half way through the trail there are some amazing views and rock formations. This singletrack ends at Secret Passage where you can continue to explore the trails in Klonzo.

Like Dunestone,  Boondocks can be done as a single loop from the lower Klonzo parking area or as part of a bigger hike (try Klonzo - Lower Loop).  

Starting from the top end of Boondocks, you'll be at the edge of the mesa top looking down over a red dirt valley littered with clusters of white sandstone formations. Follow the purple paint stripes to the right (Dunestone is bright green). 

The trail descends quickly through a break in the rim, across a saddle and around to another intersection. Stay right to take the eastern leg of the Boondocks loop - a more open and rolling feel. Going left will take you through more twists and turns among boulders.  Both legs end up at the bottom of a wash at an intersection with Dunestone.  From here it's a short punchy climb up and over to get back to the lower Klonzo parking area.
This two-way trail connects the western, lower trailhead and parking area to the 4-way intersection of Midway Trail, Roller Coaster Trail, and Redhot Trail.
This trail heads to the south from Willow Springs (Arches Loop), providing access to a number of other trails in the heart of the system. To stay on this trail, look for the turquoise markings.

You can hike this both directions, either as a way down to Dino-Flow or a quick direct shot from the dino tracks parking area up to Alaska and Nome.

Almost 100% sandstone slickrock - great little connector.
Multi-use: hiking and mountain biking.

The dirt sections are smooth through rock outcroppings and up and down small drainages.  The climbs are short and not technical, but the trail does go up and down a lot. This trail is not to be missed!

The white paint on the slickrock section is fading away, but it's still easy to find your way.

Hildalgo is a half-mile connector trail between Wildcat and 7-Up. Most use it to create a loop using these. It can be used as a climbing route back near the tops of the Wildcat and Whirlwind.

The trails in this system reflect the rugged and challenging terrain they are built within. Tight corners, constant grade changes are present. Surfaces vary from hard pack to slickrock to a bit of sand as the trails wind their way through pinion pines and rock canyons, all the while delivering unparalleled views of the majestic Moab area.

This is a new section of singletrack trail giving creating an optional route around a particularly rocky and torn up section of the original 7-Up OHV route. This trail intersects Wildcat at about its halfway point near the top of the ridge. Users will find that this hike-around offers gentle terrain and more pleasant surface than the original section of 7-Up.

The trail is hard to find but runs just to the left of the chain link fence by the BST. The first few hundred feet are a class 2 scramble with loose rock and some exposure, then it levels out and remains steep but safer the rest of the way. The trail isn't as well defined as the Dry Canyon Trail and disappears slightly in a few spots, but it was easy to follow and you stay along the ridge the entire time.

You can start this trail from the Sherryville trailhead off of Terrel Avenue. It runs downhill south to the reservoir. After a little over a mile you cross a road and connect with the main loop around the water. The loop is great. Pretty flat. You end up at a neat park with a lot of crossfit equipment and a beach volleyball court. There are also some fake bouldering rocks. The trail crosses over the dam and then connects back together.

Starting on the east side of the trail, there is a small parking area at the end of a paved residential road. From there, you start heading east, and climb up onto a shelf at the base of some stunning cliffs. The trail follows this shelf, moving up and down periodically, around the contours of this base. 

The trail connects with Tom's Canyon Trail and ends up in another residential area. You can pair this trail with a few other trails to make longer outings.
Short but steep. The route is pretty straight but very rocky and lots of roots. Head straight up the path and the falls will be visible about 5 minutes in.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

This is a redrock trail with some great views of both Kanab and the canyon. The ascent/descent in the middle, though well signed, is tricky, particularly if descending. If you are making a loop with the Squaw trail and the hiking and/or ATV connector, consider going counterclockwise to make ascend on this trail.
This is a flowy trail that was built with mountain biking in mind, but it's also great for hiking/running and can be used to link up longer routes in the Southview system.
Land Manager:  Utah DNR - Goblin Valley State Park
Land Manager:  Utah DNR - Goblin Valley State Park

Mount Wire is a cool summit over SLC, worth it for the views and for the workout, and maybe for the paraglide launch if that's your thing. There's also a small lookout tower on top, and you can climb into it (at your own risk) for an even better view.

Most people reach the top of Mount Wire summit via George's Hollow Trail which goes past The Living Room. And while that may be the nicer trail, it stays icy/muddy for a lot longer than this south-facing trail. The caveat of the south trail is that it's very steep, going more or less straight up a ridge line. It's unmaintained, rugged, and loose underfoot in some places, making it a bit hazardous in the downhill direction.

So you might take this alternative route if you want a dry hike in the spring or if you want a better burn for hill training. To make a loop with this and the standard trail, I recommend going up this south trail and down George's Hollow, but you can pick your poison.
Land Manager:  Talisker Club
$5 day use parking only.
$5 day use parking.

This trail makes part of the Spirit Arch and Petroglyph Canyon hike, which visits this and the adjacent canyon to the south.
Watch for snow, even in early July. This trail connects two beautiful trails.
