Land Manager:  USFS - Dixie National Forest Office
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

This is a trail that has been reclaimed by the Forest Service from a man who was mis-managing his private property. Specifically, he was falsely marking this trail as being within his private property boundaries. After setting the mountain-side on fire a few years ago, the Forest Service found out about this, and made him re-mark his property boundaries. 

Anyhow, this trail drops off the South Hooper Ridge Trail along the gas-pipeline to the canyon bottom, then follows it up to where it re-meets the ridge trail further up. Enjoy this shady alternative. It is best done in this direction to avoid a need to ascend the steep section of the gas-pipeline.

Stay out of private property. You'll see signs that clearly mark the boundaries.
The Skyline Villas Road is used to gain access to the bike path know as Maple Syrup or can be simply used to connect other trails.
Land Manager:  Farmington Parks & Rec
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

Similar to the easy Jasper loops, Jurassic is an alternative route to Dino-Flow, EKG, or the Copper Ridge 4x4 ways to get up from the lower parking lot to the upper end of the Klondike Bluffs area.

It's a new trail as of summer 2013 and it's obvious some thought went into keeping it a fun, smooth, trail along the bottom contour of a bluff. The trail is mostly buffed out dirt with a patch or two of slick rock and/or sand so beware of mud and rutted areas after a storm.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

The Big Hole Loop is a unique trail that takes you by the old iron ore mines. The route has about 500 feet of climbing and offers a bit of a thrill as you hike on the edge of an iron mine pit. It is worth a trip to at least check out the old iron mines.  Watch for other trail users.

From the central Moab Brand area parking lot, take the wide doubletrack path, which leaves the parking lot going east. In a few hundred yards, turn right to start onto the Lazy/EZ singletrack.  Stay right on EZ when the Lazy joins in from the left. From there, the hike winds along the base of the ridge, with just enough rocks and tight turns to keep it fun. 

After a little over a mile, the trail makes a hard right and goes up a short climb to join up with the Bar-M Loop. Stay right and look for the Bar-B trail marker. 

As you descend this trail gets harder and harder as it drops to the junction with Killer B.  If Difficult trails are not your thing, you can skip Killer B and loop back around to Lazy/EZ on an easy doubletrack. 

This loop can be used in either direction.
Land Manager:  Tooele County  Parks & Recreation

The trail begins at a small dirt parking lot at the end of a dirt road. The trail crosses a rocky slope at first and then is nice and rock free for the rest of the way. There are a few steep parts, but otherwise the incline is manageable.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

Keep your ears open for mountain bikers.
This is a simple hike-out trail. It gets progressively narrower as you go from south to north and has a pretty rolling descent.
Manti City plows up to the power plant and Patton is a just about a half mile up the road.
Outlaw has a few rock features and is a smooth singletrack trail that provides an optional loop connection to the Race Course Loop.
Its a bit rough around the edges.
Keep a look out for mountain bikers.
This trail generally requires a long approach from either side to access, but is worth it for the excellent views.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

More Hoes is an more rugged trail that climbs to the top of a mesa overlooking US-40. This trail has several tough sections including steep climbs, loose corners and rock drops. Access More Hoes via Got Milk? or Retail Sale.
Small parking lot.
Parking at the Chuckwalla lot is free.

This trail begins at the top of the hill before the main road drops into Blacksmith Fork Canyon. There is a new parking area that is paved. 

The trail immediately drops 100 feet as it parallels the highway. It ends at the Blacksmith Fork River Trail.

Wrangler and Rowdy are loop trails adjacent to and accessed through the Horsethief Campground. These are designed primarily with kids in mind however they offer a great, albeit small, taste of what hiking in the greater Moab area is like for any novice or anyone here for the first time. 

Featuring a bit of slickrock, a little sand, twisty corners and some step up/downs from small rock ledges they are a preview of what one will find throughout the rest of Moab on a much larger and challenging scale. 

If you are not staying in the campground, please park outside the gate near the dumpster area, or contact the Host and ask permission to park within the campground. Both trails start at a map kiosk marked ‘Camp Trails’ on the Buckskin Loop of the campground.

Wrangler is the easiest of the two trails as it wanders an almost mile long twisting route all within the fenced area of the campground. Some small ups and downs and various little obstacles keep the attention focused and speed limited. This is a great area for kids to spot squirrels, rabbits and lizards as well.
Land Manager:  Tooele County  Parks & Recreation

This is often a better descent from the north ridge, because it avoids the fairly steep section at the end of the north ridge. Along this connector, you can keep up a good pace, even as it gets fairly steep.
A short, steep climb from the main entrance road takes you from the main park road to the top of a ridge where you can connect with the Prospector Trail.

The Practice Loop is the perfect place to start. It is a great warm-up as well as a great trail for beginners. The trail has small features deigned for mountain bikers to work on.

This trail is the start of a much larger trail system and most use it to connect to the multitude of other trails in the system.
This loop features smooth sandstone slickrock with minimal elevation changes that make this a perfect beginner loop. Be sure to check out the dinosaur footprints!
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

Old Trench Road #181 is actually singletrack. It began as a line for erosion control and then has been reclaimed by nature over the years.

The route starts by dropping in from Ridge Trail #157 and then mellows out into a nice traverse. Through here, you'll be hiking through aspens and open meadows with nice views of the surrounding peaks.

As the trail rounds a ridge, it starts a steady downhill to Holman Trail #039. From here, you'll have two options, both steep and rugged descents. Continue on Holman Trail #039 for a short section and then stay left on Holman Ridge - Cabin Flat #172 to access Mill Canyon #40.

Stay on Holman Trail #039 for a rugged and rough adventure to FR 085.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

From the parking area, this two-way trail begins on the other side of a small gate (remember to secure it behind you) and travels up the base of a nearby bluff. It soon winds through a scenic jumble of large boulders. 

There's a little rolling terrain as Inside Passage follows the contours of the slope, but a few spots of well-laid rock work make for easy going. Hikers may catch a refreshing breeze at the top of the next rise before the trail curves down to pass between two huge boulders on the way to join the Klondike Bluff 4x4.

In the spring, a few varieties of wildflower bloom along the trail and add small drops of color to the surrounding rocks, dirt, and sagebrush.

This trail forms the easiest loop available at McCoy Flats when done with And Cookies. It is an easy trail that parallels the road.

Cross Canyon is a great trail with multiple access points to other trails in the Klonzo network. Access to the trail is from the upper Klonzo parking area from Borderline.

Hiking north you can access the following trails in order of appearance: Dunestone, Secret Passage, Borderline, Snippet and Wahoo.

Out of the parking area, Cross Canyon is a bit of a grind but mellows out into rolling trail with S-turns through boulders a few wash crossings.

Wrangler and Rowdy are loop trails adjacent to and accessed through the Horsethief Campground. These are designed primarily with kids in mind however they offer a great, albeit small, taste of what hiking in the greater Moab area is like for any novice or anyone here for the first time. 

Featuring a bit of slickrock, a little sand, twisty corners and some step up/downs from small rock ledges they are a preview of what one will find throughout the rest of Moab on a much larger and challenging scale. 

If you are not staying in the campground, please park outside the gate near the dumpster area, or contact the Host and ask permission to park within the campground. Both trails start at a map kiosk marked ‘Camp Trails’ on the Buckskin Loop of the campground.

To access Rowdy, follow Wrangler Loop to the left (clockwise) from the kiosk for a short distance until you come to a gate. Go through the gate making sure to close it behind you. This starts the Rowdy loop. 

There are many more challenging features here than on Wrangler. This trail joins a spur of the Chisholm Trail for a short distance but then separates once again, all of this is clearly signed.

The trail is a great somewhat technical work out. Most often this trail is accessed by hiking another trail to the north and taking this one back. If used that way, it can be done as a downhill trail and is a bit easier that way.

Flat wide path along the canal, wonder gravel route if you don't want to take the BST.
Multi-use: hiking and mountain biking.

This is a convenient connector that can be used to build short loops in the upper Mag 7 area. The trail itself is relatively flat and easy, so you get a bit of recovery time. Watch for jeep traffic when crossing Gemini Bridges Road. 

Some common ways of using this connector would be to descend the upper half of Bull Run and return by Getaway. You could also descend Getaway from the west, or climb up it from Arth's Corner from the east to use this connector to access the bottom portion of Bull Run. Just remember that Bull Run is for descending only, so plan your hike accordingly.

Earl's Trail is similar to other trails out at Three Peaks as it is sandy and rocky. Unlike a lot of the other trails, it does not have any slick rock. It is a good optional connection for the Race Course Loop and definitely worth adding to your hike. Watch out for other trail users.

This is described from the north (high end) of the trail since you'll most likely be coming down this after ascending one of the other trails, though it's good either way.

From the top, descend down a wide, slightly sandy wash.  It's much smoother than neighboring trails here.  There's no slickrock, and it's not painted here.  After threading through a shallow canyon, keep an eye out for the UFO trail on the left - it's easy to bomb right past it.

From here, you'll be able to hike more slickrock, following the gold dashes down bumpy terrain, passing EKG, then Dino-Flow, and finally out to Copper Ridge 4x4.

The southern of the two Baby Steps Singletrack Loops is shorter and not quite as good as the northern one, but it's still a lot of fun.  This one is all singletrack dirt with no slickrock, and it wiggles its way around small drainages and rock features.  It's mellow and enjoyable.

Be careful finding the beginning.  Look for the prominent trailhead sign and don't be tempted by tire tracks going off on suspicious trails.  They do actually link up to this trail, as it comes extremely close to Baby Steps Loop 4x4, but stick to the designated route.

The trail starts at the top of the Giant Steps Express Lift.  Stepping off the lift, the trail starts to the right. Initially the trail co-exists with the Color Flow bike trail, but the two soon split. Beyond this point, there are no bikes allowed on the Vista Trail and no hikers allowed on the Color Flow Trail.

The trail meanders down the mountain, following a similar path as the Color Flow Trail, crossing it a few times, but generally out of sight. The frisbee-golf course also follows a nearby route. The trail is generally well signed when needed as it intersects numerous service roads and bike trails.

Towards the bottom, the trail closely parallels the Color Flow and Timberline trails (within sight of each other).  Near the end, the trail just kind of fades away. The last sign pointed a vague direction towards the lodge, but the trail seemed to disappear.  No worries, the lodge is easily reached cross-country down the hill.

The trail could also be hike uphill for added exercise, but the trail signs seem to be pointed for downhill traffic.
Land Manager:  USFS - Dixie National Forest Office
Land Manager:  USFS - Dixie National Forest Office
Land Manager:  Utah DNR - Goblin Valley State Park

This short side trail leads to the tip of the rim of Little Ruins Canyon. Two circular towers were once overlooking the canyon. Enjoy spectacular views down the canyon with the Ute Mountains in the background.

This trail connects the Square Tower Unit and Holly Unit in Hovenweep National Monument. It starts at the campground loop and heads south towards Little Ruin Canyon. Just 100 yards in, it may appear as if the trail ends, but it actually drops down into a very narrow fissure in the rock before emerging into the canyon just a few dozen yards later. The trail is obvious to follow from here. Within Little Ruin Canyon, the trail initially stays on the northern side, but after half a mile drops into the canyon wash. Follow the dry bed another half mile until you reach the junction with Keeley Canyon. Turn left here, following the wash for 100 yards before heading up the eastern side onto the elevated grassy slope. From here on, the trail heads north, occasionally passing a dry creek bed until about 3 miles in when the trail goes up the western side of the canyon, right on the border to Colorado. The trail levels again just a fifth of a mile later and reaches the Holly ruins at 3.4 miles. The first notable sight is Holly House right at the canyon rim. The trail turns left, circling the canyon head and passing Tilted Tower before reaching a small parking lot at the end of a dirt road.

Loop circumnavigates the end of the mesa above Bloomington. The singletrack trail and is accessed from The Art of Motorcycle Maintenance using the dirt road.

This trail departs from the Navajo Lake Campground and takes switchbacks through a forested drainage to the top of the ridge. This ridge is part of the Virgin River Rim, or the boundary of the watershed that forms the Virgin River in Zion National Park. From the top of this trail you can find an overlook with a distant view of the national park. Look for the pointy sandstone mesas that form Zion's magnificent skyline.

Hike this trail as an out and back on its own, or combine it with the Virgin River Rim trail and the Navajo Lake Loop trail to make a roundtrip loop of about 6 miles from the campground.
Flat trail following an old flume route. Generally very easy but has the occasional washout spot.

trail_name: BST: Grandeur Peak Trailhead to Pipeline Trail
description:
New as of 2023, this is the long-awaited connector to link the Bonneville Shoreline Trail from Pipeline to Grandeur Peak Trail. Together with the short paved section over the freeway, this connector completes the BST between Parleys Canyon and Millcreek Canyon.

While hiking this somewhat steep trail you'll get expanding views over the city of Millcreek and eventually the lake. Use the trail to reach the viewpoint at the west end of Pipeline Trail or continue farther along the Bonneville Shoreline Trail in either direction.

Huge thanks to Salt Lake County, city of Millcreek, Bonneville Shoreline Trail Committee, and Utah Trails for making this trail a reality by purchasing private holdings after years of negotiations.

The Albion Basin Summer Road begins at the Albion Base Area parking. It climbs very gradually over its course from 8700ft to 9500ft. The grades are mild with only a few areas above 10%.

At mile 1.9, the Catherine's Pass Trail ascends eastward. At mile 2.2, Germania Pass via East Greeley begins on the western side of the trail. At mile 2.4, the end of the Upper Albion Meadows Trail meets this trail.

This trail takes you to Cave Peak, but I believe it is more commonly referred to as Pyramid Peak. The trail goes up a steep section of the gas pipeline that is sometimes skied in winter. The trail starts about a mile and a half up the Mueller Park Trail.

Note that there are several descents from Cave Peak, such as one leading into North Canyon, but all of them (except for the one you came up) lead to private property or private roads that have been recently closed due to vandalism. It's quite unfortunate. 

This trail, as far as I'm aware, is the last possible way to the peak that avoids private property. Of course, until the peak itself is claimed by a private land owner (it would not surprise me); there will probably always be a way you could bushwhack to the peak. If it was completely surrounding by private property, but not claimed as such, then I guess you'd have to parachute in. Better to take a chopper so you could get out. If, however, the air-space gets privatized, you're out of luck until mankind invents molecular transport.

From the peak, there is a trail heading east along the ridge-line towards Rudy's Flat, but it turns into a bushwhack pretty quick.

Comment Type:

 Lost or Found Item
    self-destructs in 30 days

    Opinion
This trail begins above Jacob Hamblin Park. It goes up a canyon and follows a narrow wash. It is rocky and a somewhat technical ascent in places, with some scrambling required. Tons of fun.

trail_name: BST: Cedar Hills to Grove Creek
description: This trail follows the maintenance road for the Salt Lake Aqueduct, and is very level. It is often called the Bonneville Shoreline Trail, but none of it is officially designated as such; Pleasant Grove calls it the Bench Road Trail. It can be accessed at the Grove Creek Trailhead, Timpanogos Cove Park, or the new trailhead on Bayhill Drive.

Savor the steepness at the start, then enjoy the ridge above the north-facing evergreens, especially if there is snow on it.  There is plenty of glissading you can do.  I recommend an ice-axe for the final section of the trail before Francis Peak.  Believe me, hiking it without an ice-axe is no fun.

The Spiro Trail is one of the most popular ways to get from town into the hills.  To reach the start of Spiro, either take the Silver Spur trail from the ski area base or head through the golf course neighborhood to where the trail hits Crescent Road.  

This multi-use trail gets a lot of downhill mountain bike traffic in the summer, so if you're trying to avoid other users, hike early or late in the day.  The trail itself is a lovely trek at a consistent grade uphill through aspens and clumps of wildflowers.  The numerous early switchbacks provide views galore.  You'll cross so many ski runs, and part of the navigational enjoyment is to orient yourself to where you ski in the winter months.

The path between the picnic area and the visitor center really doesn’t fit the usual or official definition of a trail, but it is a nice route and a good introduction to the geologic and human history of Fruita. The path is especially suited for those who arrive early at the campground and need both a little exercise after pulling in and some information about Capitol Reef. It is also the only trail in the park where dogs are allowed, so Rex and Fluffy will like it too. 

Campers can access the Visitor Center Trail by picking up the east end of the Fremont River Trail that borders Loops A and B on the north side next to the river and heading downstream (east) past the Gifford House to the bridge on the Scenic Drive. Others should park at the picnic area, which is 1.0 mile from the visitor center on the Scenic Drive. The path is located just across the Scenic Drive to the west.

Wherever you choose to start, the trail meanders across streams and beside historic orchards rich with heirloom apple varieties, among other fruit, to eventually end in the Capitol Reef Visitor Center Parking Area.

This content was contributed by author Rick Stinchfield. For a comprehensive hiking guide to Capitol Reef National Park and to see more by Rick, click here.

From the Ghost Falls Trail, take the first trail on the left. At roughly 0.2 miles, a spur trail splits off to the right while the Lone Rock Trail continues down into a gully near a small stream. On the other side, the trail turns to the east (right) and follows a fairly steep and sandy climb to reach Lone Rock.

This one-mile loop flat trail on the banks of Little Cottonwood Creek goes through a great natural area with beautiful views of the Wasatch Mountains. The trail surface is loose gravel, but is very wide and easy to hike on.
It is a popular horse-riding area.
The trail mostly follows a natural gas pipeline and isn't much to look at. It's very straight and there aren't any roots or trees on the trail..

To get here, drive up W Canyon View Dr. on the west side of St. George until it ends and becomes BLM land. You'll drop down from the mesa into the desert where you'll see trails going off in every direction. 

As you look west from this point, there is a large gap in the land that rises before you. Stay to the right side of this gap and follow the gravel road up toward a water tank and parking lot.  Climb to the parking lot (high clearance vehicles can drive to the lot), continue on to the fence at the top of the climb.  

The trail starts with an short easy climb but is soon followed by a nice downhill. There are signed easy and difficult routes to get you down the Acid Drops (this is primarily directed at the bikers on route). Once you are at the bottom of the Acid Drops turn left and continue down. 

Be aware that mountain bikers tend to ride this trail quickly. Be alert and aware of other trail users.

Starting from the turnoff to the entrance of Granite Flat Campground, this forest service road is more or less the continuation of the road coming up from Tibble Fork towards Silver Lake Flat. The road is very well maintained and pretty obvious and easy to follow. The road ascends gradually and is pretty manageable on the way up, and although there are loose rocks and some erosional features, it is mostly a well maintained road through a beautiful forest. 

After about 0.75 miles, there is a split for the Deer Creek-Dry Creek Trail #043 off to the left, which is a great trail to access Box Elder Peak. After approximately 2.5 miles, Silver Lake Flat finally comes into view, which can be really beautiful depending on the water level. 

A little after 3 miles, the road passes by a parking lot for the Silver Lake Trail and soon thereafter crosses a (sometimes sizeable) creek. The creek can usually be easily crossed on a series of rocks if you don't want your feet to get wet. After crossing the creek, the road continues up past a series of small camping areas in a clearing near the creek, and then eventually "ends" by transitioning into a pair of other forest service roads, one going up toward American Fork Twin Peaks and the other heads off to the west towards a couple of other places.

Miner's Basin Road is a dirt forest service road. It is accessible from the La Sal Mountain Loop Road (paved). The road is used by mountain bikers and hikers to access the Miner's Basin Trail. As with other FS roads in the area, there are some great views of Castle Valley from Miner's Basin Road.

Miner's Basin Road and Miner's Basin Trail is a grueling climb of almost 1,800 feet. of elevation gain in three miles!

This trail will lead you to Lamanite Arch from The Gulch. Depending on the season, this trail may be very difficult. The thicket, especially in the lower parts of the canyon, can be impenetrable. As an alternative, you may want to climb up the side of the canyon, but it is not easy to find a path there either. Only shortly before you reach Lamanite Arch, you'll actually get a good view. Up to that point, you are bushwhacking your way through very dense riparian vegetation.

Shay Ridge Trail can be accessed from any of three different parking areas. Both of the southern areas are reached by driving a long ways up FS Rd 079. Most vehicles will park near the start of FS Rd 0354, leaving hikers to travel 1.5 miles up the rough road. If you have a capable 4WD vehicle you may be able to drive FS Rd 0354 to the trailhead. The northern parking area is adjacent to the Aspen Flat Trail (018) and is suitable for higher clearance AWD and 4x4 vehicles.

Starting from the top, remember to sign in at the kiosk at the trailhead. After that, you'll be on the main Shay Ridge Trail, a signed OHV trail - not open to vehicles larger than a Razor ATV. Follow the tire treads as they climb along a grassy knoll through swaths of forest. The view of the Abajos to the east (right) is quite rewarding - just make sure to also keep an eye on your footing as you navigate the baseball-sized rocks that litter the trail.

At the top of the climb, make a fairly sharp left below a bald knob. Look for a clearing and picnic table on the left where you can hang out for a bit before starting your descent. From here the trail descends steadily for several miles.

Continuing on, you'll follow similar tire tracks down through aspens, It's quite beautiful when the leaves are changing. Roughly halfway through the descent is the intersection with the Blue Creek-Tuerto Trail (014). From here, the trail leads through one last dense grove of aspen before completing its final miles through low vegetation. The tread is increasingly rocky until it goes through a loose sandy section.

Bottom out at a trailhead/parking area that marks the start of Aspen Flat Trail (018). Retrace your steps or complete the long, loop on Aspen Flat Trail (018).

trail_name: Owachomo Bridge to Sipapu Bridge Trail
description:
This trails starts across the road from either the Sipapu Bridge parking area or the Owachomo Bridge parking lot. So keep an eye out for cars. 

If you are going from the south to the north, this trail will cross the Bridge View Road again after only a few minutes, before descending a little drainage gully and then meeting the Bridge View Road again. You'll meet the Kachina Bridge Shortcut Connector on your left. Keep going through the flat and shade-less trail. You'll encounter some large rocks that offer a bit more interesting hiking right before arriving at the Sipapu Trail parking area. 

This whole trail is devoid of shade so bring lots of water and sunblock as it will be very hot.

From the split in the trails from the Steam Mill Trail, continue along the foothills of the Steam Mill and White Pine drainages. The trail crosses through meadows and forests, and across a dry creek bed (it was dry in the fall when I went; maybe it has water in the spring). 

After ascending for a few hundred vertical feet, the trail drops down into the White Pine Creek drainage and crosses the creek, and then starts to ascend again toward the headwaters to the west. This part has some beautiful views of White Pine Creek and follows it closely enough to hear the rushing waters for most of the rest of the trail. 

The trail then passes through some more aspen forests and after about 800 feet of elevation gain, where it meets up with the White Pine-Bunchgrass Canyon Trail.

Although this trail lacks the stellar overlooks of the other trails in the area, it has cool rock formations such as ledges and caves that are fun to explore. There are a couple of short sandy sections, but this is a pleasant connector to better trails.

This is a fun hike! Scrambling/climbing up past the waterfall isn't terribly difficult, and neither is getting down that section. Just be careful you don't generate rock-fall for those camped out at the base of the waterfall.

Once past the scrambling section, you'll find a trail that quickly becomes difficult to follow. Just follow the creek as it bends southwest. Before the creek bends west, leave it and hike straight up the slope, bushwacking off-trail through dense brush and scrambling across scree.

Once up above the rock ledges, look around, and you'll find a trail that takes you to the cabin. Consider coming down the well-worn trail that follows the north ridge of Adam's Canyon. Or you could continue on up to Thurston Peak, then come down the south ridge of Adam's Canyon where there is another well-stocked cabin along the way.

Note that Adam did not build the cabin, so I don't refer to it as "Adam's Cabin." Also, I believe that users of the cabin are expected to replace what food they eat with food they bring. Don't bother reading the cabin log. There's a lot of innuendo in there.

For those who are very short on time or unable to complete longer outings, this near-roadside ruin is worth a quick stop. The lollipop shaped walkway is flat, wide, and easy to navigate. A large info board explains the ruins and some history. There is a round, covered kiva-like structure, a "tower," and some old walls to look at. Retrace your steps back to the parking area.

From the left side of the Swamp Canyon overlook pullout (about 5 miles south of the visitor center), join the marked Sheep Creek Connecting Trail when it branches from the Swamp Canyon Connecting Trail. Head north through dense forest eventually circumnavigating a prominent butte. 

After the first flat mile above the rim, descend off the lip into the Sheep Creek drainage. Pass a handful of hoodoos and traverse a wooded canyon before meeting the Under-the-Rim Trail and the Sheep Creek Trail at a 4-way intersection at the canyon bottom.  

This trail was formerly used for moving sheep around to different grazing areas.

If you're planning to make a loop that combines Sheep Creek Connecting Trail, Under-the-Rim Trail and the Swamp Canyon Connecting Trail, the preferred direction is clockwise.

This trail is accessed from a pull out parking area off the main park road near the 9 mile marker.  

Descend about 500 feet through a wooded gully and parallel a wash. The trail ends at the intersection with the Under-the-Rim Trail. The Swamp Canyon backcountry campsite is just north of this junction (no facilities or water).

Although it is primarily used by backpackers wishing to reach (or escape from) the approximate midpoint of the Under-the-Rim Trail, it does provide more casual users with access to the rim and a way to see the great views over Mud Canyon (continue 0.15 miles north on the Under-the-Rim Trail).

Tibble Fork #41 is a lot of fun if you like challenging downhills.

From the intersection of South Fork of Little Deer Creek Trail #252 and Ridge Trail #157, the trail begins with great views of the surrounding mountains. From there, the route is a steady descent through a mix of forest and open meadows. About midway through, the trail crosses the Mud Springs #173 trail.

Tibble Fork ends with a series of switchbacks, bringing you to its namesake reservoir.

The trail starts seven miles north of I-80 on Stansbury Island Road at a metal sign that says "Stansbury Island Interpretive Trail". Next to the metal sign is a short access road that leads east to a visible BLM parking area and trailhead for a mountain Stansbury Island Trail. At the end of the trail, you'll see an interpretive kiosk called "Capt. Stansbury Visitor Overlook", a restroom and parking area. To the northeast, there is Boulder Point trail to Boulder Point.

You can start right at Highway 191, but the first 2.8 miles are easy to drive for passenger cars, and this section of road is not too interesting, so it's better to start from the Klondike Buff parking area, 2.8 miles along this road.

From here, the first section is very popular as it's the main access for all of the Klondike trails.  Use a variation that parallels the road to the west and is a little less sandy than the main road, 

Where the Klondike trails start, you'll take a right to continue on a slightly bumpier road until you hit an enormous section of slickrock.  You might find dinosaur prints if you're lucky.

Continue until you get to the border of Arches National Park, continue by a short ways to a great viewpoint of Arches National Park and the La Sal mountains.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

From the Franklin Basin Road, this road turns to the left (west) and passes by some small campgrounds (and some parking spots) as it starts to ascend into the Steep Hollow drainage. The road winds up through some forests and crosses a creek, and in many places is very rocky with large boulders in the road. 

The road levels out somewhat and passes a junction with the Shorty's Cutoff Trail, and the creek comes back into view. The road more or less follows the creek for most of its existence as it then heads toward Doubletop Mountain, which is one of the most spectacular peaks in the Bear River Range. In certain places you can catch a glimpse of this peak from the road if you get a break in the trees. 

Eventually, the road ends at another parking area (that you can really only get to with a pretty high clearance vehicle, as the road is in pretty bad shape down closer to the Franklin Basin Road) where the road then turns into a small trail that leads to a small basin just below Doubletop Mountain. This road is more of a means to an end rather than an amazing trail in and of itself, but it does offer some views of some pretty amazing country in the Bear River Range and has great opportunities to see wildlife if you go at the right time.

trail_name: BST: Battle Creek to Grove Creek
description: Currently, this is not an "official" segment of the BST, as it passes through private land. However, the landowner seems to allow both motorized and non-motorized access in this area.
Land Manager:  Basin Recreation

The wide and friendly Mojave Trail starts next to the Viking yurt on the Home Run ski run.  Wind comfortably down a consistent grade through scattered stands of aspen trees and open scrub.  Keep an eye out for wildflowers and valley views.  This is a popular multi-use trail, so expect to share it with bikers.  After crossing several ski runs, the trail ends at a switchback of the Mid Mountain Trail just below the end of the King Con chairlift.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.

This trail is good if you have already visited one of the other bridges on your way to Kachina Bridge and want to take a shorter route back to where you parked. 

From the parking area at Kachina Bridge, cross the street to pick up this trail. It is very flat and only a mile long. However, it is very exposed with only short juniper-like trees that don't offer shade. So be ready for heat and the sun. 

The path is clear and easy to follow as it passes through bio-crust - stay on the trail to protect this fragile, living soil. A few drainages will appear as trails, but when you actually encounter the Owachomo Bridge to Sipapu Bridge Trail it will be clear.

FS Road 0354 is a steady climb with amazing vistas. It's a rocky, sustained 4WD road. It's kind of steep in places. There are at least two viewpoints with excellent views out to the northwest. The grassy hillsides have an interesting terraced farming look reminiscent of the countryside in Tuscany. It's surprising to find that in Utah!
The trail starts at the Legacy Nature Preserve parking and runs between the Legacy Nature Preserve and the Legacy Highway to Center street. It is a simple, plain, low altitude trail.

This 4x4 road leaves from 191 and heads gradually uphill, eventually reaching HWY 313. Along the way, you'll encounter beautiful rock formations, a detour for Gemini Bridge itself, and typical desert shrubland.

The lower section - from Highway 191 up to Arth's and the actual Bridges - is very steep and sandy, but is useful as an exit from the midpoint of Mag 7, to avoid the Portal exit.

The upper section from there to Highway 313 is not recommended at all; use Getaway instead. This part of the road gets a lot of high-speed jeep and motorbike traffic, and is heavily used by oil mining trucks.

Note that this road has absolutely no respite from the sun. If you do hike this, wear sun protection and carry a lot of water. Most just use this to connect other trails.
Land Manager:  Bonneville Shoreline Trail Coalition
After a long, bouncy road, many people (and most with low clearance vehicles) will choose to park on the main road and take this stretch of road to approach the Moon House Trail.

This lollipop trail starts in a wooded copse just off the BST: Flight Park to Mike Weir Trail. After a few quick switchbacks, it tops out a non-spectacular viewpoint. This view is not significantly better than what can be seen from parts of the BST Trail.

The Blue Creek-Allen Canyon Trail (013) is accessed at its southern end by FS Road 095 and ends in a junction with the Tuerto Trail (011). The trail is on the longer side for the area, but its difficult nature and stretches of indistinct routing suggest it's not the most popular. Still, if you're looking for a challenge or want to create a loop from nearby trails, the Blue Creek-Allen Canyon Trail (013) may be the ticket.

There isn't a defined parking area at the southern end of the trail, but with a little searching, you should be able to find a spot to park that's not too far away. The trail begins along an old, rocky road that follows a rounded ridgeline for about a mile until it reaches a large dusty intersection. From here, head to the right through a nice patch of trees. Almost immediately, you're confronted with a split in the singletrack.

This is one of the unclear sections of this trail, as the area can be heavily crossed with animal trails. Taking the left split, you soon cross over a drainage zone before climbing toward a scree field to the east. Depending on the conditions, you may be better suited to head right. Just make sure you end up at the scree field.

On the other side of the scree, the trail soon crosses a streambed and heads into a thick forest. The initial climb here is steep, but it soon backs off. As the trail leaves the tree cover, it heads toward a large bare slope. 

This is another area that suffers from an unclear path. Follow the narrow singletrack across a creek crossing as it angles up the barren slope en route to a nearby saddle. If the trail fizzles out before you reach the saddle, simply head right and keep climbing until you reach the clearly defined Skyline Trail (015). The view along this section is superb, so make sure to spin around a few times.

Almost immediately, the trail separates at the edge of the saddle. Head for a wide gap in the vegetation that leads to the rounded ridgeline to your left, then turn to the right and keep climbing. After a half mile, the trail drops down the other side of the ridge and begins the long descent.

Over the next two miles, the descent drops through the forest, briefly follows the edge of a ridgeline, and enters a large meadow. Head diagonally right through the grass to momentarily overlap with the Blue Creek-Tuerto Trail (014) before they separate next to two old buildings. Head to the left for more steady descending.

As you approach a reservoir, plenty of trail braiding obscures the main route. Fortunately, it doesn't matter too much, just pick up the trail in the small valley just past the reservoir. The trail remains pretty clear from here to its end in a junction with the Tuerto Trail (011).

Although this is more of a functional trail, linking the southern part of the Under-the-Rim Trail with the main park road at Ponderosa Point, it does have nice scenery. From the parking lot, surmount a short hill via switchbacks and enjoy broad views up and down the rim. 

Duck into a more wooded area for the gradual descent off the plateau. After navigating a series of steep switchbacks to pass the pink limestone cliffs, head down the ridge that forms the southern edge of Agua Canyon. You'll arrive at a junction with the Under-the-Rim Trail at approximately 17 miles from where it started at Bryce Point.  

From this junction, enjoy views north of multicolored Agua Canyon and Natural Bridge. Rainbow Point is above the skyline to the south.

Chug along this smooth dirt road to access the top of Crescent Mine Grade (CMG), Apex, and other quality Jupiter area trails.  You'll pass some huge old mining operations, then Shadow Lake, and finally end all the up on a saddle and the Wasatch Crest Trail.

The Pipeline Trail can be started either from the Outlook to Pipeline Connector or can be picked up from just in front of the St Regis Hotel (where the Deer Hollow ski run goes under the road tunnel). The trail surface is smooth packed dirt and winds back and forth across multiple ski runs. It goes through several stands of dense evergreens, aspens, and other scrubby trees with minor views up and down valley. The trail ends by following the Keetley ski run down, stopping at the Mountaineer Express chairlift.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.

Use Caution! This trail is VERY popular with mountain bikes and hikers should be aware of their surroundings and other users on the trail. 

This trail will either be one of your favorite experiences in Moab, or your worst nightmare. There are a lot of rocks, bedrock, ledges and other technical features and its often covered in mountain bikers; but everything is doable. There's some exposure in spots, although it's not as edgy as the Portal.

The trail follows gold blazes painted on the rock. The old blue dots can still be found if you look, and they lead you to a higher level of challenge. At the end of this trail, you can continue to Portal, or take Poison Spider more of a jeep route, but also much less exposure.
Land Manager:  Tooele County  Parks & Recreation

Hop Creek Trail (022) begins off of Vega Creek Trail (164). Right away, the trail follows an old road trace, making two creek crossings before staying close to the banks of Hop Creek for the next two miles. Before departing this section, look for a colorfully striped mesa.

From here, the trail continues to climb toward Shay Mesa through scrubby juniper. The contours and ridges in this area translate into easy going along the sandy trail. You'll cross over a few more drainages, but don't expect much in the way of shade.

At around four miles, the trail descends into a shallow draw before ramping up for a steep climb on the other side. After navigating an additional series of drainages, the trail pretty much heads straight up, with little in the way of switchbacks to offset the grade. 

This steady climbing peaks at a small ridge at the edge of the mesa. The views are pretty nice from here, which is great because you'll probably feel like taking a break. An easy beeline to the FS Road (104) is all that separates you from the end of the trail.

Starting from the BST: Flight Park to Mike Weir trail, the Lexie and Ethan Trail climbs steadily but at a mild grade. After a couple of switchbacks, the undulating trail pops in and out of the shade created by scrub oak. Soon the Red Rock Climbing Crag becomes visible, and then the trail passes over the top of the crag. The trail contours along the hillside, and passes below a new neighborhood. The scenery opens up, and the road noise increases greatly! After a few more turns, the trail ends at a T intersection with the Red Potato Trail. The trail in general is a little wider than usual and smooth. There are few roots and rocks but since the trail is new, the surface is not well-packed as of fall 2018.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

The navigation on this hillside behind the lodging lining Deer Valley Drive East can be confusing at first, mostly due to multiple junctions, similar trail names, and signposts that label trails in addition to giving directions to neighboring trails. 

The Gap Trail switchbacks up the dry exposed hillside from Finn's trail, making several close approaches to the St. Regis funicular. Pass upwards through scrub oak and thistle towards the hulking St Regis Hotel. Attain the ridge and delight in the wide-lens views of the Jordanelle Reservoir and Deer Crest neighborhood. Proceed along the ridgetop and drop down over the summit into the dry valley below. 

A signpost at a level section of trail gives the option of going directly back to the Mid Gap trail (via the Gap Connector) in the direction of the McKinley Road guardhouse or heading downhill towards the St. Regis Hotel. The Gap Trail towards the St. Regis descends first through more dry, shrubby undergrowth before turning sharply away from the St Regis to follow along the top of a roadway retaining wall. The Gap trail ends just uphill of the McKinley Road guardhouse.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.
This is an access road that leads up toward Jupiter Peak. It ends at Pioneer Ridge Rd.

From the top of the Homestake chairlift near the Silver Lake Lodge base area, follow the Sultan Connection ski run downhill towards the east.  The grade is gradual and pretty gentle.  This wide, sunny service road passes through aspen groves and denser forest before reaching the base of the Sultan Express chairlift.  From here the trail makes a couple of switchbacks uphill to arrive at the scenic deck and overlook.  This is where the Sultan Connection trail ends and the Sultan Out and Back begins.  

Note: bikes are not allowed on this trail.

This trail serves as a connector between North Creek Road (079) and the Red Ledges Trail (019). From the east, it descends from North Creek Road (079) for less than a mile to intersect with the Red Ledges Trail (019) at a craggy corner. The trail is short, but can be rough in places.
This is a continuation of Stansbury Island Interpretive Trail that leads to the north end of the island. About half of the trail goes through sandy beaches, the other part is a hard packed dirt road.

This is a pleasant, mostly level connector between the Deer Crest and Spin Cycle trails. Enjoy the easy stroll contouring around Deer Crest neighborhood with good views of Bald Mountain and the Jordanelle Reservoir.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.
$5 day use fee

This multi-use trail is open for downhill travel only, whether you are a biker, hiker, runner or something else.  Starting just under the Payday chairlift at a switchback mid-way down Jenni's Trail, Loose Moose heads downhill at a mellow grade ensured by the numerous switchbacks.  End up at another random switchback on the lower part of CMG (this part of CMG is for downhill biking only, but folks on foot can go either direction).  You'll cross a couple of ski runs, but mostly be hiking through aspen woodlands next to the alpine coaster.
Bikes are not allowed on this path.

This is the old service road that was used to get the heavy machinery up to the top of the mountain to build the ski resort.

This trail is easy to miss if you are not looking for it. The trail breaks from the Wolf Creek Canyon Trail at roughly the 2-mile mark. It is located on the south-southeast side of the Wolf Creek Canyon Trail about 2 miles from the Powder Mountain Road.

Starting in the treed hillside just south and above the Deer Crest neighborhood guard house area (near Snow Top Road), the Upper Village Trail crosses and then follows Deer Crest Estate Drive briefly. Rock cairns mark where the trail leaves the road and descends through scrubby trees towards the Mountaineer Express chairlift. Gentle switchbacks wind through mature aspens before crossing the Deer Hollow ski run, rejoining the trees and finally ending at the base of the Mountaineer Express chairlift.  Note:  bikes are allowed on this trail.

From the intersection with the Cowley Canyon/Herd Hollow Road (FR 047), the road ascends and passes by a couple of springs. Soon after, it reaches an intersection with the Richards Hollow 019G trail, and from here the trail affords great views of The Elbow area and the surrounding forests.

Continuing along, the road skirts around The Elbow from above, and soon passes the junction to the Card Canyon East trail (which goes off to the right and drops down Card Canyon). From here, the road continues and gives great views of the ponds that form in the upper end of Richards Hollow, as well as the beautiful conifer forests all around. Soon, it passes the intersection with FR 151, which takes you down to Card Canyon West, and shortly thereafter splits into two roads. 

The main road, which continues up the mountainside is FR 168 which goes up to Logan Peak and the Providence Canyon, Millville Canyon areas. The fork to the left is the continuation of the Adams Corral FR 052 road, which soon passes another trail that goes down to Richards Hollow, and then eventually ends at Adams Corral. Near the corral is another trail that splits off and goes to Providence Cave, a great cave for spelunking that plenty of local spelunkers explore.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

The White Pine Basin is simply a short cut if you have someone in your group that needs to get back to the parking area. If taken from the parking lot, there is a mild descent, followed by a moderate climb once you've intersected with the Brim Trail. The trail in the meadow is a simple doubletrack with no features worth mentioning. There is an excellent viewpoint at the end of this trail, but you'll want to use the Brim Trail to access the overlook! The meadow section of the trail is a gentle doubletrack, but the views are pleasant and worth while.

It's worth noting that the character of the trail changes slightly after the meadow portion. From about the 1.25 mile mark, the trail becomes a strenuous little out and back with an amazing view of the Pineview Reservoir. Just head up the doubletrack on the south end of the Brim Trail and work your way to the top. The view looking back into Powder Mountain is spectacular and worth the grind. 

Even though this is a doubletrack it does not feel like you are on a dirt road. Instead, the trail seems more like you are on parallel single tracks. You'll need to switch from one side to the other as you work your way up and down the trail.

This is just a dirt road (closed to cars, but open to ATVs and bikes), and not a destination, but it connects to some great singletrack, including the Spring Creek Trail (159) and Robertson Pasture Trail.  It's got a smooth surface, and the hills are a little steep but technically easy.

Throughout this trail, you'll encounter plenty of intersecting road-traces. As a general rule of thumb stay on the most traveled route. The area is quite dry and there is little to no shade for the duration.

From the bottom, follow the sandy road as it switchbacks away from South Cottonwood Road (106). As you pass below an early outcropping, a beautiful view briefly opens into the steep white canyon to the west. Settle in for a steady and moderate climb at the one mile mark before the trail levels out for a few miles of rolling elevation.

This reprieve ends as the trail rounds a low ridgeline and starts to climb in earnest. The next mile is a sustained, steep climb up another ridgeline. The surrounding vegetation does get greener as you gain elevation, and your chances of catching some shade improve as well. Make sure to take a look over your shoulder as you go, the vista below is quite nice.

The climbing doesn't stop, but it does back off for a short section before making another steep, non-stop climb to the end of the trail where this route connects to an unnamed Forest Service Road.
This road leads from the top of Pioneer Lift near the Summit House) to just below the summit of Jupiter Peak.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

The Lower Village Trail starting from the base of the Mountaineer Express chairlift passes gently downhill though pleasant woods paralleling Deer Hollow Road. Upon leaving the trees and reaching a maintenance shed, turn left on Deer Creek Estates Drive, cross Deer Hollow Road, and follow Deer Hollow Road downhill until just past Harmony Drive. 

Turn left on a dirt and partially paved unmarked service road before reaching another ski area maintenance shed. Follow the wide, grassy Jordanelle ski run downhill, through a tunnel to the base of the Jordanelle Gondola.  The Lower Village trail is about half singletrack, half dirt road/ski run.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.

Little Stick can be used in either direction to connect the Silver Lake Village area at the base of Bald Mountain with the Deer Crest area trails. It is primarily a doubletrack dirt road that follows the Little Stick ski run. Several short sections are covered by singletrack switchbacks which can get loose and rutted. There are a couple of peaceful wooded sections and fleeting views of the Frog Valley, but otherwise the trail is pretty unaesthetic.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.
This connector road links Powerline to Jupiter bowl.

The navigation on this hillside behind the lodging lining Deer Valley Drive East can be confusing at first, mostly due to multiple junctions, similar trail names, and signposts that label trails in addition to giving directions to neighboring trails. Gap Bypass trail is named as such on the paper summer trail maps, but is not given this name on the trailside signposts. 

Gap Bypass trail leaves from Finn's connector and traverses around the scrub covered hillside. The gentle uphill ends at the Deer Crest neighborhood guardhouse on McKinley Gap Road. Enjoy views of the ski runs on Bald Mountain as well as down to the lakes of Frog Valley. This dry trail does not provide much shade but scattered wildflowers appear instead. The trail surface is packed dirt with some small loose rocks.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

This short and steep climb connects the Tuerto Trail (011) to the Skyline Trail (015). Parts of this infrequently used trail are faint, so it shouldn't be your first choice for making a loop, but it's an option if you need it.

Holman Ridge - Cabin Flat #172 is the extension of Old Trench Road #181. This route is very steep with a section of sustained grades of 18-22%. It is also very rugged with rocks and a loose tread surface. In other words, it's not everyones idea of a good time.

This is a good bail-out option from Holman Trail #039 to access Mill Canyon #40.

This forest road starts off of Highway 191 and climbs through a gap in the snow fence into the hills east of Dyer Mountain. The road is well defined and generally maintained. 

It's most frequently traveled to reach the yurt at the top of Bassett Springs Trail #152B (Grizzly Ridge Yurt). It also intersects with Trail #153, Trail #153A, FR #279, and FR #575.

Starting from the east, the trail is dead flat and uninteresting until you cross the road.  On the western side of the road, the trail gets much more interesting as it winds through juniper, sage, and Mormon tea plants.  

Overall, this is hardly a destination trail, but makes for good loops for a longer hike.

The Gooseberry Trail (445) connects East Gooseberry Road (094) with South Cottonwood Road (106) over the course of three miles along a rocky road trace. The rocky road trace has plenty of steeper sections that can be slick after periods of rain or snow.

From the top, look for the faint road trace off of East Gooseberry Road (094). The trail heads south-east along a gradual climb through scattered trees. After less than a half mile, the trail begins to descend as a grand vista of the adjacent valley comes into view.

Soon, the rocky doubletrack meanders alongside an eroded slope. At no point does the trail get too close to the edge, but curious hikers may want to venture out for a better view. A steep descent continues over the next few miles and many of the views are once again hidden.

Eventually, the grade mellows out near a meadow, followed by a series of switchbacks. As the trail continues, it turns north and maintains a gradual descent until it connects with South Cottonwood Road (106).

The trail can be used in either direction, but this description is for a clockwise loop: 

Leaving the Bar-M Loop at the Circle-O's southern trailhead, hike 1/4 mile on dirt doubletrack to the berm bowl at the junction with the Rockin' A trail. This is where the real fun begins.  

Head right (SE) from the berm bowl to follow the Rockin-A trail (it's well signed). The path is marked by a rust-colored line painted on the Entrada sandstone. Follow this line for nearly 2 miles as it winds through tight turns, over quick dips, and down short steps. This slickrock is slightly more difficult than the Circle-O trail, but more fun. You'll come to the junction with Bar-M and can return to the trailhead on this trail, or continue south on the Bar-B Loop.

This is most often done as a way to connect all the great singletrack in the Klondike Bluffs area.

Starting on the south end, after reaching the start from Baby Steps South, you'll wind around washes on slickrock and sand.  It's never very difficult, but the white paint trail markers are sometimes hard to find, so keep your eye out.  You'll pass several nice singletrack options (Baby Steps Singletrack Loop 1 and Baby Steps Singletrack Loop 2), some dinosaur tracks if you can find them, and then arrive at the junction with UFO.

Take a right and continue wandering around slickrock until you intersect the Klondike Bluff 4x4.  Go left, up a steep ridge, and then enjoy some descending through the Salt Valley.

After a long straightaway, you'll take a sharp left and climb back up to the mesa, where you'll again wind around slickrock that is smooth, and fun!

There are excellent signs at all trail intersections.

The navigation on this hillside behind the lodging lining Deer Valley Drive East can be confusing at first, mostly due to multiple junctions, similar trail names, and signposts that label trails in addition to giving directions to neighboring trails. Mid Gap trail is so named on the trailside signposts but is not labeled like this on the paper summer trail maps.  

Mid Gap starts from junction area just uphill from the Deer Crest neighborhood guardhouse on McKinley Gap Road. Head up steep switchbacks through thistle, scrub oak and stunted aspen trees. The angle eases off considerably after the switchbacks end and the trail contours back around the hillside towards the St. Regis funicular. Views of Bald Mountain and the lakes of Frog Valley appear in the distance.  Note: bikes are allowed on this trail.

This is the best way, in my opinion, to connect the Bonniville Shoreline Trail to Deuel Creek. You could, of course, take the road, but you may have to compete with vehicles on their way to the rifle range.

As its name suggests, the Reservoir Canyon Trail (008) climbs out of Reservoir Canyon from its intersection with the Vega Creek Trail (164). 

From the trail junction, the first half mile is spent gradually winding through scrubby bushes before tackling the slope. All of the elevation gain is focused into a series of tightly packed switchbacks that end atop the canyon rim on Forest Road 096 (Maverick Point).

While you'll earn some nice views as you slog up the trail, its rocky and rutted nature doesn't make for the most enjoyable hike.
Watch out for mountain bikers.
This foot-traffic only trail is short and mostly flat. The path travels to a bit of high ground that affords reasonable views of the surrounding hills and the town of Draper.
Land Manager:  Farmington Parks & Rec

The West Wagon Road Loop Trail departs from about mid-way along the Wagonwheel Trail #168.  Begin by heading northwest on a gentle climb along a bench. The two-track trail surface can be muddy after a rain, but otherwise consists of somewhat loose, rocky patches interspersed with more packed areas. 

Travel though piney woods and dry, scrubby vegetation. Soon after a steeper gradient, hikers arrive at a "Y" intersection where the "head" of the lollipop starts. Complete the circle in either direction, visiting primitive camp spots, an overgrown overlook and nice views of a rugged cliff-band to the north. The trail is faint here, so keep your eye out. Upon arrival back at the "Y" intersection, tramp down the "stem" of the lollipop until it deposits you back at the Wagonwheel Trail #168.

Fall colors are pretty here, but be sure to wear orange during hunting season as this area is popular with motorized hunting parties.
This gradual forest road heads west from Highway 191. It's most frequently traveled to connect Bassett Springs Trail #152A to FR #181.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

Used to link several popular singletrack trails in the area, this trail is generally smooth, but there are some loose rocks here and there.  The grade is gentle but continuous, and this is one of the easier ways up to the top of the Klondike Bluff trail system.  

On the slickrock sections, the white paint is wearing away, so pay attention.

This pleasantly mellow trail starts out nearly flat. After a few turns, the trail goes over two small foot bridges. The gentle uphill continues through stands of short scrub oak and grasses. Before long, the trail ends at the top of the hill at the map and information kiosk.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

The Little Valley D Line trail is smooth and not too rocky. It pops in and out of scrub oak as is descends the hill. This hand-built trail is more narrow, but still very mellow. This multi-use (bikes & foot traffic) is bi-directional.
Land Manager:  USFS - Manti-La Sal National Forest Office

This is the only viable place to scramble out of Buckskin Gulch once you're deep in the narrows. The 100 to 200-foot walls run nearly uninterrupted for a dozen miles, except for at this one spot. Here, the canyon makes a 90-degree turn and on the outside wall there is a low-angle gully leading to the rim. It requires some scrambling, but is doable even with a heavy pack on. The passage is about 6.5 miles below the Wire Pass/Buckskin confluence, and 5.3 miles above the Buckskin/Paria confluence.

People have used this passage to escape floodwaters in the canyon, but there's no guarantee you'll be able to reach this spot once water starts flowing. It's good to know about, not to rely on.

You could also use Middle Pass if something else goes wrong on your trip, like an injury or hypothermia. The caveat is that once you get up the gully and onto the rim, you're pretty much in the middle of nowhere. You'll have to hike through open desert -- following a wash and scrambling through a slabby cliffband -- for more than a mile northward to reach a primitive dirt road. 

Don't expect any cars to come by once you're there. It is possible to walk to either White House Trail or House Rock Valley Road in a few more hours using two-tracks and washes, but you'll need to navigate miles of rather featureless desert to be successful.

Backpackers primarily use the lengthy Sheep Creek Trail either as a way to exit the park (in the N-S direction) or as a way of entering the park without paying a fee (S-N direction).  

From the 4-way intersection with the Under-the-Rim Trail and the Sheep Creek Connecting Trail, the Sheep Creek Trail follows Sheep Creek wash along the canyon bottom. Descend past Swamp Canyon, the Sheep Creek backcountry campsite and cross the national park boundary near Short Canyon as the canyon progressively broadens.  

After Mud Canyon, the trail joins a dirt fire road (115B) and turns to the east. Navigate past Pasture Wash and the heavily wooded Noon Canyon before reaching the Sheep Creek Trailhead and parking area at the end of Sheep Creek Flat Road. The trailhead is on Dixie National Forest land, just inside the BLM land boundary.

This is a typical Wasatch butt kicker. It starts off mild but only grows steeper, smartly approaching the main Bonneville Shoreline Trail (BST): Dry Creek to City Creek  trail, arriving at Bobsled after about a mile of mostly shadeless hiking. 

This route begins from a residential neighborhood, so please remember to be respectful on your hike!

This trail runs through beautiful terrain and often punishing conditions. It parallels, then joins with the Behind the Rocks road to complete a roughly 15-mile loop.

With about twice your recommended daily allowance of sand, the trail is harder than the mileage would suggest. Many stretches are more likely to be used by OHVs than anything else.

Despite a few really nice sections, this one really isn't worth doing unless you're curious about the famous 24-hour race that used to be run here.

trail_name: Boneville Shoreline Trail: Centerville to Bountiful
description: This is a nice section of the Bonneville Shoreline Trail that connects the Parrish Creek Trail #608 and Deuel Creek Trail. In places, it overlaps with the fire-break road, so watch for cars and ATVs.
Extreme caution should be used around any steep snow field, snow with water moving underneath, waterfalls, and/or cliffs.
Land Manager:  City of Draper, UT - Parks and Trails

There is a tangled mass of spaghetti-like trails in this southeast corner of Manti La Sal National Forest. The Bull Dog Trail is a good choice for folks looking for a straight-shot descent from the South Peak area to Highway 191 and nearby Devils Canyon Campground. 

The Bulldog Trail (also called 504) branches off the 0084 fire road and heads south. The downhill hiking is gentle at first, passing through wooded sections and occasional pretty aspen groves. Substantial erosion has gouged some hiker-eating troughs in this trail. When not negotiating these tricky spots, the trail becomes more mellow and enjoyable, dropping at a steady gradient. The smoother sections are a bit monotonous as you wind through dense forest. 

Although there are fewer turn-offs and confusing trail junctions on this trail than others in this area, towards the bottom you need to be careful to stay on the right track. Some paths dead-end in campsites and others send you into the wrong drainage. Use the Hiking Project mobile app to stick to the right trail. A final short uphill climb at the end brings you back to civilization with a bit of a view before the trail terminates at Alkali Pt. Road.

Fall colors are pretty here, but be sure to wear orange during hunting season as this area is popular with motorized hunting parties.

The First Ridge Trail would be do-able all but for a brief strip of private property overlapping the jeep road.  The trail shown here circumvents that private property. Unfortunately, much of this trail is very overgrown and hard to follow. Nevertheless, it is worth noting it as an alternative to trespassing.

On my hike, I ran into a swampy section, followed by a decomposing deer carcass. The trail can be accessed from the end of Highland Oaks Drive where there is an easement where I am fairly certain hiking is legal. It would help if there was a sign, but at the time of this writing, there is no sign whatsoever, only a trail and some parking spaces.

This is a straight, flat, somewhat sandy old Jeep road.  It takes the path of least resistance in connecting the north and south Klondike Bluff trailheads.  There is no climbing, no technical difficulties, and not much of a reason to use it.

You might take this trail if you need to get back to a trailhead but there are much better options to either side: Jasper Loop and Agate Loop to the west or Dino-Flow to the east.

From when this trail leaves the Prospector Trail at its eastern end, it oscillates between sink-in silt and golfball-sized rocks, with a few steep elevation stretches.  There are some open-face rock areas

For anyone unfortunate enough to have chosen the Cottonwood Hills Trail or Bracken's Loop, the Spanish Wash may well be your fastest escape back to Prospector Trail from the torture. Sadly, it is torture as well.  

As far as washes go, this one is pretty bad, as it is almost entirely sand. There is one area of flat rock about halfway through that offers some respite from constant sinking and trudging, but it's about 50 feet. Suitable for masochists and hardship training runs, not much else.

This gradually narrowing 2-track dirt road climbs part-way up the flank of South Peak. The trail surface is somewhat loose and rutted. Climb up two benches through scrubby trees and dry vegetation, occasionally getting glimpses of the hillside from small clearings. This is a less interesting and less pretty way to reach the Abajo Peak Rd (FR0087) from the Wagonwheel Trail (168). 

Fall colors are pretty here, but be sure to wear orange during hunting season as this area is popular with motorized hunting parties.

This short, nearly flat beginner trail is designed for both bikes and foot traffic. It is wider than the others in this trail system, so it is more forgiving and allows for multi-directional travel. This trail has very little elevation gain and is smooth. It goes up the gut of the valley, eventually ending at the top of the instructional trail system. The trails in this area are well signed.

Starting from a fenced spot off the Main Line Beginner Trail, this foot-traffic only trail heads uphill towards Ann's Trail and the tunnel. This trail tends to be eroded and a bit overgrown by scrub oak.

Land Manager:  Utah Division of Wildlife Resources - Farmington Bay Waterfowl Management Area

trail_name: Great Western Trail: Sessions Mountain Road to Francis Peak
description: This section of the GWT starts at the top of Ward Canyon Road which is also the North end of Session's Mountain Road and the South end of Sky-line drive.  Most cars can reach it without any problems.  The trail begins as a wonderful hike descending through thick forest with a few stream crossings and craggy formations before reaching the Farmington Flats area.  This area is characterized by a curious color of sand (I always called it "indian sand"), and is frequented by ATVs.  The Farmington Flats area is a network of ATV trails that includes Chicken Creek Loop, and Gold Ridge.  (I've motor-biked them both many times.)  Exiting Farmington Flats area, you arrive at the shed that begins Francis Peak road.  From here you can drop into Morgan or go down Farmington Canyon.  Continuing on the GWT, you'll eventually reach Francis Peak.  Best to go around it than over it to avoid radiation exposure.  Beyond that, you reach a fork.  Going right takes you to the Smith Creek Lakes (there are 3 of them.)  Going left continues the GWT towards Thurston Peak.  Now go to the description for GWT: I-84 to Francis Peak.
Land Manager:  USFS - Uinta, Wasatch & Cache National Forests Office

This easy multiuse trail winds along a sandy wash through stunning red rock formations. It is one of the more scenic trails in the Red Canyon area.

This trail is quite the scramble up to the Farmington canyon road switch-back, then it traverses West while still being quite the scramble with a tad bit of exposure here and there.  The trail then becomes much more manageable as it links up with the Francis Peak trail.

On the start of the scramble up to the switch-back, it is not uncommon to encounter items that people have dumped from the canyon road above, or broken skeets (clay targets) left over from shooters.

I've done this trail many times in the summer and winter (with snow shoes). Branching off the Davis Creek Loop trail, you immediately cross a creek heading north, then the trail turns eastward and becomes steep and overgrown. Pop-can bottoms here (and in almost all other places, by the way) help you make sure you're on the right path as the trail becomes harder to follow. 

Eventually you'll find two trees, each with a pop-can bottom, marking the right-turn you'll need to make to begin the first switchback that will take you to the south shoulder of the false peak, I believe called Midway Peak.  Hike right between the two said trees. As you continue upward, the trail may disappear, leaving you to look for the next pop-can bottom or other form of tree-tag. If you don't see one, just follow your nose.

On the return, you sometimes have to look behind you to see the pop-can bottoms as they were placed to be visible for someone ascending, not descending the trail.

This trail begins at the midpoint access for Blowhard Mountain Trail, and it can be used as a starting point for trips into the Ashdown Gorge Wilderness. Crystal Springs is a natural seep that forms a wet meadow, where domestic sheep are often grazed in the summer. The rest of the trail continues downward into Long Hollow within the wilderness area.
